// 您的主函数：在开局时/DOM 变化时调用 function onGameWindowChanged(mutationList, observer) { updateQuestionBanner(); createAllCandidateBoxes( currentCandName, // 使用全局变量 currentCandTitle, // 使用全局变量 currentMateName, // 使用全局变量 currentMateTitle // 使用全局变量 ); updateadvisor(); // === 加入到这里 === addDataCenterButton(); // ================== } function updateadvisor() { if(e.song == 1) { campaignTrail_temp.election_json[0]["fields"].advisor_url = "https://i.imgur.com/lDLy5pZ.gif"; } } const observer = new MutationObserver(onGameWindowChanged); observer.observe(targetNode, config); //全局变量 e.LeeTengHuiAttacks = 0; e.BlackGoldConnection = 0; e.PoliticalReformPromise = 0; // 索引 0 對應第一題，索引 24 對應第二十五題 /** * 更新问题横幅并创建两位候选人的信息框。 */ const MOD_IMAGE_URLS = [ 'https://i.imgur.com/8pQwu3d.jpeg', // 索引 0 (第一題) 'https://i.imgur.com/kCQjAOF.png', // 索引 1 (第二題) 'https://i.imgur.com/eB78myg.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/zV7QMtK.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/tKsDsH5.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/rPN5xBZ.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/9NRR5Ku.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/2DTHsLD.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/XHFiziB.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/xDIeBYm.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/DR3R8bg.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/itp64ca.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/guwIgaR.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/RPT88Oi.png', 'https://i.imgur.com/9BSJGH1.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/8A26BsA.png', 'https://i.imgur.com/pCQIvRD.png', 'https://i.imgur.com/QoRFvQT.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/6eQe9Mr.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/CobYZrj.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/IMs8sHi.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/VUnvKrk.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/GpJIl7S.jpeg', 'https://i.imgur.com/Q7eY0wG.png', 'https://i.imgur.com/Xgzqlmo.jpeg' // ... 請確保這裡有 26 個 URL (索引 0 到 25) ]; function updateQuestionBanner() { // 1. 獲取當前問題的索引 (直接就是 0, 1, 2...) const currentQIndex = campaignTrail_temp.question_number; const picWidth = 160; const picHeight = 203; // 2. 查找 DOM 元素 let questionBanner = document.getElementById("campaign_sign"); document.getElementById("header").src = "https://i.imgur.com/KBV8y6h.png"; // 檢查舊元素 if (!questionBanner || questionBanner.nodeName != "DIV") return; // 3. 創建圖片元素 let img = document.createElement('img'); let imageSource = null; // 4. 核心 MOD 判斷邏輯：確保索引有效 if (currentQIndex >= 0 && currentQIndex < MOD_IMAGE_URLS.length) { // ** 直接使用索引從 Mod 陣列中取圖 **Chang Rong-wei-wei imageSource = MOD_IMAGE_URLS[currentQIndex]; // 額外：如果您想設定背景，可以在這裡執行 $("#game_window")[0].style.backgroundImage = "url(https://i.imgur.com/cwmho9L.jpeg)"; } else { // 索引無效時的後備圖片 imageSource = 'https://i.imgur.com/Default_Fallback_Image.png'; console.warn(`Mod 警告: 索引 ${currentQIndex} 無效，使用後備圖片。`); } // 5. 設定圖片 src img.src = imageSource; // 6. 替換舊元素 questionBanner.replaceWith(img); } /** * 遍历并替换 candidate_pic 和 running_mate_pic 元素， * 将它们包裹在带有指定样式和文本的容器中。 */ /** * 遍历并替换 candidate_pic 和 running_mate_pic 元素， * 将它们包裹在带有指定样式和文本的容器中。 * * @param {string} candName - 候选人姓名 * @param {string} candTitle - 候选人职务/头衔 * @param {string} mateName - 副手或政党名称 * @param {string} mateTitle - 副手职务或政党头衔 */ function createAllCandidateBoxes(candName, candTitle, mateName, mateTitle) { // 设置固定的尺寸 const picWidth = 160; const picHeight = 203; // ========================================================= // 1. 候选人 (candidate_pic) 信息框创建逻辑 (左浮动) // ========================================================= // ⭐ 直接使用传入的参数 candName 和 candTitle const originalPic = document.getElementById('candidate_pic'); if (originalPic && !document.getElementById('candidate_box_wrapper')) { const wrapper = document.createElement('div'); wrapper.id = 'candidate_box_wrapper'; wrapper.style.cssText = ` border: 2px solid white; padding: 5px; text-align: center; display: inline-block; background-color: #e5e5e5; color: black; float: left; margin-right: 15px; margin-left: 10em; max-width: ${picWidth + 10}px; `; const pic = originalPic.cloneNode(true); pic.id = ''; pic.style.width = `${picWidth}px`; pic.style.height = `${picHeight}px`; pic.style.objectFit = 'cover'; const nameDiv = document.createElement('div'); nameDiv.textContent = candName; // ⭐ 使用参数 nameDiv.style.cssText = 'color: black; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 5px;'; const titleDiv = document.createElement('div'); titleDiv.textContent = candTitle; // ⭐ 使用参数 titleDiv.style.cssText = 'color: black; font-size: 0.9em;'; wrapper.appendChild(pic); wrapper.appendChild(nameDiv); wrapper.appendChild(titleDiv); const parent = originalPic.parentNode; parent.replaceChild(wrapper, originalPic); } // ========================================================= // 2. 副手/政党 (running_mate_pic) 信息框创建逻辑 (右浮动) // ========================================================= // ⭐ 直接使用传入的参数 mateName 和 mateTitle const originalMatePic = document.getElementById('running_mate_pic'); if (originalMatePic && !document.getElementById('running_mate_box_wrapper')) { const mateWrapper = document.createElement('div'); mateWrapper.id = 'running_mate_box_wrapper'; mateWrapper.style.cssText = ` border: 2px solid white; padding: 5px; text-align: center; display: inline-block; background-color: #e5e5e5; color: black; float: right; margin-left: 15px; margin-right: 10em; max-width: ${picWidth + 10}px; `; const matePic = originalMatePic.cloneNode(true); matePic.id = ''; matePic.style.width = `${picWidth}px`; matePic.style.height = `${picHeight}px`; matePic.style.objectFit = 'cover'; const mateNameDiv = document.createElement('div'); mateNameDiv.textContent = mateName; // ⭐ 使用参数 mateNameDiv.style.cssText = 'color: black; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 5px;'; const mateTitleDiv = document.createElement('div'); mateTitleDiv.textContent = mateTitle; // ⭐ 使用参数 mateTitleDiv.style.cssText = 'color: black; font-size: 0.9em;'; mateWrapper.appendChild(matePic); mateWrapper.appendChild(mateNameDiv); mateWrapper.appendChild(mateTitleDiv); const mateParent = originalMatePic.parentNode; mateParent.replaceChild(mateWrapper, originalMatePic); } } e.cyoa = true e = campaignTrail_temp e.Economy = 0;//经济政策 e.CoalitionUnity = 0; //国亲团结度 e.MainlandFriendly = 0;;//对陆友好度 //开始变量 e.start = 0; e.ref = 0; //面对的候选人 e.song = 1; // ⭐ 狀態標誌的初始化： if (typeof campaignTrail_temp.soongShiftApplied === 'undefined') { campaignTrail_temp.soongShiftApplied = false; } function SoongIssueShift_PartyCoalition_minus() { // 檢查標誌，如果已經執行過，則立即退出，防止分數累積。 if (campaignTrail_temp.soongShiftApplied) { console.warn("SoongIssueShift_FixedDelta_Safe 已經執行過，跳過調整。"); return; } console.log("正在執行宋楚瑜議題的固定幅度 (-0.05) 調整..."); // 🌟 關鍵修正：定義所有政策的固定 Delta 為 -0.05 (或 0.05) 🌟 const adjustments = [ // PK 338: 原始 0.5。調整 -0.05，最終 0.45 { pk: 338, delta: -0.05, name: "Party Coalition" }, ]; const issueArray = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_issue_score_json; adjustments.forEach(adj => { const id = issueArray.findIndex(p => p.pk === adj.pk); if (id !== -1) { const issueFields = issueArray[id].fields; const currentScore = issueFields.issue_score; // 核心邏輯：將當前分數加上固定的 Delta (-0.05) issueFields.issue_score += adj.delta; console.log(`PK ${adj.pk} (${adj.name}): 從 ${currentScore.toFixed(3)} 調整了 ${adj.delta.toFixed(3)} 變為 ${issueFields.issue_score.toFixed(3)}`); } }); // 設置標誌，表示已完成調整 campaignTrail_temp.soongShiftApplied = true; } // 狀態標誌的初始化： if (typeof campaignTrail_temp.soongShift_PK339_Applied === 'undefined') { campaignTrail_temp.soongShift_PK339_Applied = false; } function SoongIssueShift_Provincial_minus() { // 檢查標誌，如果已經執行過，則立即退出，防止分數累積。 if (campaignTrail_temp.soongShift_PK339_Applied) { console.warn("SoongIssueShift_Provincial_minus 已經執行過，跳過調整。"); } // 清除標誌，允許下次調用時再次調整分數 function ResetSoongShiftStatus_PartyCoalition() { campaignTrail_temp.soongShiftApplied = false; } function ResetSoongShiftStatus_Provincial() { campaignTrail_temp.soongShift_PK339_Applied = false; let playerPolling = (pop_vote.find(p => p.pk === e.candidate_id)).pvp; let i = 0; pop_vote.sort((a, b) => { return a.pk - b.pk; }); //广告 if(newAd) { newAd = false; campaignTrail_temp.banner1.src = getRandomItem(ads); } // 獲取陳水扁、宋楚瑜和連戰的原始普選票數據 // 假設 e.candidate_json[0] = 陳水扁 (ID 67) // 假設 e.candidate_json[2] = 宋楚瑜 (ID 69) // 假設 e.candidate_json[4] = 連戰 (ID 68) let soong_pvp = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[2].pvp; let lien_pvp = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[4].pvp; let chen_pvp = campaignTrail_temp.candidate_json[0].pvp; let diff = soong_pvp - lien_pvp; // 宋楚瑜減去連戰的百分點差異 // KMT 發動棄保的信心基礎：連戰民調不低於陳水扁 1% (0.01) 以上，就代表 KMT 有信心發動棄保 const kmt_confidence = lien_pvp >= (chen_pvp - 0.01); // --- 情景 5: 連戰對陳水扁處於有利態勢，但低於宋楚瑜 (KMT 發動棄保) --- if (e.player_answers.includes(19991064) && kmt_confidence && lien_pvp < soong_pvp) { // 觸發「連戰對陳水扁處於有利態勢，但低於宋楚瑜」時的特殊問題 (KMT 發動棄保) campaignTrail_temp.questions_json[24] =     { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 19991136, "fields": { "priority": 0, "description": "Damn it! Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan jointly held a press conference to release a poll claiming Chen Shui-bian was first, Lien Chan second, and Soong Chu-yu third, publicly appealing to Pan-Blue voters to concentrate all their firepower on Lien Chan. This is Lee Teng-hui's goddamn conspiracy! That old bastard will stop at nothing to prevent Soong Chu-yu from being elected president! We can only rely on fate...", "likelihood": 1 } } } // --- 新增情景 7: 連戰崩盤，選票流向陳水扁 (宋楚瑜視角的噩夢：棄連保扁) --- // 條件：連戰支持率極低（< 20%），且陳水扁支持率高（> 35%），證明連戰的票正流向陳。 else if (e.player_answers.includes(19991064) && lien_pvp < 0.20 && chen_pvp > 0.35) { campaignTrail_temp.questions_json[24] = { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 19991640, "fields": { "priority": 0, "description": "God, no! The political atmosphere is completely out of control! Lien Chan's support has collapsed below 20%, but his voters aren't coming to you—they're running to Chen Shui-bian! They are executing a spontaneous 'Abandon Lien, Protect Chen' strategy to ensure the KMT and its allies lose entirely. This means our lead is a mirage, and the votes that should have been mine are now going to the DPP! The KMT's incompetence will hand the presidency to Chen! This is a total catastrophe!", "likelihood": 1 } } } // --- 宋楚瑜領先情景 (diff > 0) 且滿足先決條件 --- // 情景 1: 宋楚瑜大幅領先連戰超過 13% 且滿足先決條件 else if (e.player_answers.includes(19991064) && diff > 0.13) { // 觸發宋楚瑜大勝連戰 13% 以上的邏輯 campaignTrail_temp.questions_json[24] = { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 19991017, "fields": { "priority": 0, "description": "Damn it! This is Lee Teng-hui's goddamn conspiracy! That old bastard will stop at nothing to prevent Soong Chu-yu from being elected president! We can only rely on fate...", "likelihood": 1 } } } // 情景 2: 宋楚瑜領先連戰 10% 到 13% 且滿足先決條件 else if (e.player_answers.includes(19991064) && diff > 0.10) { // 觸發宋楚瑜領先 10% 到 13% 的邏輯 campaignTrail_temp.questions_json[24] = { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 19991101, "fields": { "priority": 0, "description": "Damn it! We can only rely on fate...", "likelihood": 1 } } } // 情景 4: 宋楚瑜微幅領先連戰 0% 到 5% 且滿足先決條件 else if (e.player_answers.includes(19991064) && diff > 0) { campaignTrail_temp.questions_json[24] = { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 19991115, "fields": { "priority": 0, "description": "Damn it! ["39.30%", "36.84%", "23.10%", "0.63%", "0.13%"]; function onGameWindowChangeCandidates() { const resultsTableHolder = document.getElementById("overall_details_container"); if(!resultsTableHolder || resultsTableHolder.classList.contains("done")) { return; } resultsTableHolder.classList.add("done"); const resultsTable = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[3].childNodes[3].children[0]; for(let i = 0; i < resultsTable.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTable.children[i]; let name = row.firstChild.innerText; row.insertCell(1); if(name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); console.log("name is:" + name) } if(i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTable[name]; } } const resultsTableHistorical = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[5].childNodes[3].children[0]; for(let i = 0; i < resultsTableHistorical.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTableHistorical.children[i]; let name = vpTableHistorical[name]; } } } const gameWindowNode = document.getElementById("game_window"); const candidateWatcherConfig = { attributes: true, childList: true, subtree: true }; const candidateObserver = new MutationObserver(onGameWindowChangeCandidates); candidateObserver.observe(gameWindowNode, candidateWatcherConfig); const style_overwrite = document.createElement("style"); style_overwrite.innerHTML = `#campaign_sign { background-color: #13366e; border-color: #b22525; } .visit_text { color:white; } #overall_result_container { background-color: #c3c3c3; } #state_info h3 { padding: 24px; border: 4px double #bababa; font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif; color: #273450; box-shadow: 0 0 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); margin: 1rem auto; max-width: 610px; line-height: 1.6; margin-right: 1em; } #switchingEst b { /* 为所有候选人的名字添加下划线 */ text-decoration: underline; /* 增加一些间距，让下划线不至于太紧贴着字（可选） */ padding-bottom: 2px; } .inner_window_sign_display{ max-height:256px; "] */ e.pages = [] e.header = ""; e.executable = [] e.final_overall_results.sort((a, b) => b.popular_votes - a.popular_votes); map = document.getElementById("map_container"); // ========================================== // 结局判定逻辑 // 候选人 ID: 69 (宋), 67 (陈), 68 (连) // quickstats[1] = 宋楚瑜得票率 // aa[1].candidate = 第二名候选人ID // ========================================== // 常量定义 const CW_LOW = 0; // 中道数值低 (偏绿或激进) const CW_HIGH = 3; // 中道数值高 (偏蓝或稳健) const PRP_HIGH = 3; // 政治改革数值高 (达标) const LEE_GOOD = 4; // 亲近李登辉因素的达标阈值 const LIEN_ID = 68; // 连战的候选人PK（独特值Primekey） const FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT = quickstats[1]; //候选人得票率 // 变量假设已赋值： const V = FINAL_VOTE_PERCENT; let exclusive_action_executed = false; // 互斥锁 // 用于存储结局简介的数组 // 1. 先確保 e.pages 和 e.executable 是陣列，防止報錯 if (!Array.isArray(e.pages)) e.pages = []; if (!Array.isArray(e.executable)) e.executable = []; let Outcome = ""; let triggered_outcome_number = 0; // ------------------------------------------ // I. 宋楚瑜获胜 (Soong Wins) - 看得票率 // ------------------------------------------ // 0A. *** 替換結局 *** 宋楚瑜獲勝 - 普京模式的強人政治 (PV > 45%) // 此結局應排在所有 PV >= 40% 的結局之前 if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] > 45) { e.pages.push(`

The Empire of the Sun

"They tried to bury us with lies, with money, and with fear. But they forgot that we are the seeds."

The streets of Taipei have vanished. They have been replaced by a surging, screaming, weeping ocean of Orange. From the high balcony of the "New Taiwanese Service Team" headquarters, the view is terrifying in its majesty. It is not a political rally anymore; it is a coronation. The rain that has plagued the city all day has stopped, as if the heavens themselves dare not rain on this parade. The air smells of wet asphalt, heavy incense, and the raw, electric scent of absolute power.

You, James Soong (Soong Chu-yu), stand before the mirror in the private waiting room. You adjust your tie. You look at the man in the glass. You are no longer the "Governor." You are no longer the "Defector." You are the President. And not just a President by a margin of error. The television screens behind you are screaming the numbers that will be etched into granite: ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%.

It is a massacre. You have not just defeated your enemies; you have annihilated them. Lien Chan and the KMT machine—with their billions of dollars and their "Black Gold" networks—have been reduced to single digits in some districts. Chen Shui-bian, the self-proclaimed "Son of Taiwan," has been crushed under the weight of your populist juggernaut. You have taken the South. You have taken the North. You have taken the Hakkas, the Minnan, the Mainlanders, and the indigenous tribes. You have united the island under the banner of one man.

Chen Wan-shui, your wife—beloved by the public as "Wan-shui Jiejie" (Sister Wan-shui)—walks over to you. She is beaming, radiating that warmth that softened your sharp edges throughout the brutal campaign. She straightens your lapel, her eyes shining with pride and relief. "You did it, Chu-yu," she whispers. "You beat him. You beat the old man."

She doesn't need to say the name. Lee Teng-hui. The "Godfather." The man who used you, discarded you, and tried to destroy you with the "Chung Hsing Bills" scandal. Somewhere in the Presidential Palace, just a few blocks away, Lee must be sitting in the dark, trembling. This victory is your ultimate revenge. You haven't just taken his job; you have destroyed his legacy. The KMT is dead, killed by the very man Lee exiled.

Chang Chao-hsiung, your running mate, the respectable doctor who gave your ticket its moral weight, is shaking hands with the staff. He looks almost dazed by the scale of the victory. "It’s a mandate for a new epoch," Chang says, adjusting his glasses. "The people didn't just want a change of government. They wanted a savior."

The room is filled with the architects of this miracle. The staff of the "New Taiwanese Service Team"—the embryonic structure of what will surely become the new ruling party—are in a state of delirium. Famous figures from the New Party, like Jaw Shaw-kong and Yok Mu-ming, who threw their tactical support behind you to stop independence, are raising toasts. They think they have elected a unificationist ally. They think they can control you. They are wrong. With 45% of the vote, you belong to no one. You are the Sun around which all planets must now orbit.

You step out onto the main floor. The roar is deafening. "Song Shengzhang! Song Zongtong!" (Governor Soong! President Soong!). It is a wall of sound that hits you in the chest.

You see the faces of the people. The veterans in their raincoats, the housewives waving orange flags, the taxi drivers who plastered your face on their cabs. They look at you with a religious fervor. To them, you are the man who actually worked. The man who visited every township. The man who fixed the roads and built the bridges while the elites in Taipei played power games. A-Bian promised them dignity; you promised them prosperity and competence. And tonight, competence won by a landslide.

A frantic aide runs up with a mobile phone. "It's A-Bian," he says breathlessly. "He wants to concede."

You take the phone. You imagine Chen Shui-bian on the other end, the firebrand lawyer finally silenced. "Mr. Chen," you say, your voice smooth, authoritative, dripping with the magnanimity of the conqueror. "You fought a spirited campaign. But Taiwan has chosen stability. I hope you will work with me in the 'Grand Coalition' government I plan to form." You hang up before he can answer. You don't need the DPP. You don't need the KMT. You are the State.

You walk toward the balcony. The lights are blinding. The confetti cannons fire, filling the air with a blizzard of orange paper. As you look out over the sea of supporters, a feeling swells in your chest—a dangerous, intoxicating expansion of the ego. You feel ten feet tall.

"My fellow Taiwanese!" you bellow into the microphone. The feedback squeals, then dies into the roar of the crowd.

"They said it was impossible! They said the parties were too strong! They said a man without a party could not lead this nation!"

You pause for effect. You raise a fist. "But look at us tonight! We have proven that the will of the people is stronger than any machine! We have proven that the 'New Taiwanese' are not Green, they are not Blue—they are the colors of the earth, the colors of the harvest!"

You look toward the Presidential Palace in the distance. You can almost feel Lee Teng-hui's presence fading, like a ghost being exorcised. You have beaten the accusations of corruption. You have beaten the "Black Gold." You have beaten the independence radicals.

But amidst the adoration, there is a shadow. With this much power—${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%—there are no excuses left. You are not a minority president. You are an Emperor. The expectations are astronomical. The people expect you to solve the Cross-Strait crisis, fix the economy, and clean up the government, all by the sheer force of your personality.

Chen Wan-shui squeezes your hand. "Smile, Chu-yu," she says softly. "The whole world is watching."

You smile. It is the smile of a man who knows he has written his name into history with indelible ink. The era of the parties is over. The era of Soong Chu-yu has begun.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/soooong.jpg?v=1765966596904"})]); } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] > 45) { // HTML Content: Highly critical op-ed in pro-Green style. All strings embedded directly. e.pages.push(`

The President’s Lie: From 'Efficiency' to 'Lifetime Dictatorship'—Who Will Reclaim the Stolen Fruit of Democracy?

— Soong Chu-yu’s 'Elected Tyranny' and the Total Loss of Asia’s Democratic Flagship

By David C. W. Chang (Researcher, North American Taiwanese Human Rights Foundation) | January 18, 2020 (Published via Liberty Times International)

Preamble: Rage and Powerlessness—A Stolen Election

As President James Soong wins his fifth presidential term in 2020 with his 'uncontested' posture, sitting overseas, I feel only utter powerlessness. The democracy we fought for was not overthrown by a military coup, but was systematically gutted by a technocrat in a suit, shouting 'efficiency,' in broad daylight, through constitutional loopholes!

This is not an election; this is a humiliation of the Taiwanese people's sovereignty! His overwhelming victory in 2000 (over 45%) should have been a moment for reform, but it became a poison for his limitless personal expansion of power. Soong, a politician forged under the authoritarian system, never truly believed in checks and balances. He only believes in himself.

I. The Core of 'Soong-Style Efficiency': The Emasculation of Democracy

What is Soong’s 'efficiency'? It is turning the Legislative Yuan into a rubber stamp, the judiciary into a tool of obedience, and reducing all dissenting voices to 'emotional noise' that 'impedes national development'!

His governance from 2000 to 2008, while seemingly stable, was actually laying the groundwork for the future return of authoritarianism. Unlike the Democratic Progressive Party's pursuit of transitional justice, he perfectly inherited and refined the KMT’s decades-long techniques for controlling the state apparatus.

Now that he is entrenched, we can only watch as he raises the banner of 'the economy,' shouting to the world: 'Look! In Taiwan, only a strongman can deliver stability!'

BULLSHIT! This is not stability—this is tyranny!

II. Chang Chao-hsiung’s Constitutional Ploy: The Putin Playbook, Taiwan’s Tragedy

What fills us with uncontainable rage is the 'half-time break' in 2008.

After being constitutionally forced to step down, Soong handed power to his loyal ally, Chang Chao-hsiung. Chang’s four-year term was a perfect constitutional drama! He was not corrupt, had no scandals, but under the PFP’s manipulation, he quietly and swiftly pushed through several key 'black-box constitutional amendments' that cleared the way for Soong’s 2012 comeback and solidified the President’s absolute control over the executive branch.

This is how similar it is to the Putin Playbook—using Medvedev as a placeholder to modify the constitution for a long-term return! They exploited the trust in the democratic system, turning our Constitution from a contract that guarantees human rights into a family register that a strongman can arbitrarily browse and alter!

When these amendments passed, how many times did we in the Green Camp shout ourselves hoarse in the Legislative Yuan and launch protests in the streets? Yet, Soong returned easily in 2012, and the public, fearing so-called 'chaos,' voted again for this constitutional vandal! Is this not the ultimate mockery of all who sacrificed for Taiwan’s democracy?

III. Taiwan, Wake Up! We Are in the Shadow of the 'Xi-Soong System'

Soong’s 2020 re-election thoroughly nails Taiwan to the pillory of 'elected dictatorship.' His system is now afflicted by the same maladies as other authoritarian regimes in Asia:

  • Like Putin, he has turned elections into a regular, predictable 'personal coronation ceremony.'
  • Like Xi Jinping, he has completely centralized state resources and the media machine, leaving no space for dissent.

When we advocate for Taiwan's sovereignty and democracy abroad, we no longer face just the external pressure of the CCP, but the systematic destruction from within—from the very 'president' we elected!

Our sovereignty has never just been about cross-strait relations; it is first and foremost the people's right to determine their own destiny! And now, our destiny is tied to James Soong’s personal political ambition.

Conclusion: Bidding Farewell to Democracy’s Beacon, Welcoming the Strongman Era

We cannot remain silent! Even if we are a minority in the Legislative Yuan, even if our voices are suppressed, and even if the fruit of our democracy is rotting, the Green Camp must unite and show the international community the truth: This 'efficient and stable' Taiwan is merely East Asian autocracy wearing democratic clothes! People of Taiwan, stop being deceived by the strongman's lies! Our freedom is rapidly slipping away!

The Teflon Governor

"They used the courts, they used the media, and they used their favorite son to lie to you. But the people saw the truth."

The numbers on the giant projection screen at the "New Taiwanese Service Team" headquarters are steady, solid, and undeniable. They are not the miraculous, gravity-defying numbers of a sudden surge, nor are they the razor-thin margins of a nail-biter. They are exactly what the internal polls said they would be six months ago, before the mudslinging began.

You, James Soong, stand with your arms crossed, watching the tally climb past the psychological barrier: ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%. In a brutal three-way war, securing over 40% of the vote is not just a victory; it is a vindication. It is a statement that the "Soong Wave" was never a bubble. It was a concrete reality that the KMT establishment tried—and failed—to demolish.

The room is buzzing with a frenetic, vindictive energy. Your supporters aren't just happy; they are angry at what they had to endure to get here. They are shouting at the television screens showing the KMT headquarters, where the mood is one of funeral silence.

Chang Chao-hsiung, your vice-presidential pick, wipes his forehead with a handkerchief. He looks at you with profound respect. "The 'Fake Polls' didn't work," he says, his voice thick with relief. "Ma Ying-jeou failed."

The name hangs in the air like a bad smell. Ma Ying-jeou. The KMT's golden boy, the Mayor of Taipei. Just days ago, he stood before the press, his face a mask of earnest integrity, and released those "internal" numbers claiming Lien Chan was surging and you were out of the race. It was a desperate, calculated lie designed to trigger the "Dump-Soong, Save-Lien" effect. It was the establishment using its most beautiful face to sell its ugliest deception.

But the voters didn't buy it. They looked at the massive rallies in Taichung. They looked at the orange flags blanketing the south. They looked at Ma Ying-jeou's trembling hands when he read those numbers, and they saw the fear behind the lie. The attempt to manipulate the "Strategic Vote" backfired. Instead of abandoning you, the people abandoned the party that thought they were stupid.

Chen Wan-shui—your wife, the heart of your campaign—squeezes your arm. She is crying, but she is smiling. "They tried to hurt us, Chu-yu," she whispers. "The Chung Hsing Bills, the lawsuits, the slander. They tried to paint you as a thief. But the people remember who paved their roads. The people remember who visited their flooded farms when the KMT ministers were sleeping in Taipei."

You look at the map. You have built a fortress. You have taken the broad middle of the electorate—the moderate Mainlanders, the economic voters, the disillusioned KMT rank-and-file, and the native Taiwanese who fear the instability of A-Bian but despise the corruption of Lien. Chen Shui-bian has performed well, likely finishing second, but he hit his glass ceiling. Lien Chan... Lien Chan has been obliterated, dragging the century-old party into the abyss of irrelevance.

The television cuts to the KMT headquarters. The scene is chaotic. Furious supporters are surrounding the building, clashing with riot police. They are screaming for Lee Teng-hui to step down. They are shouting that the party leadership betrayed them by forcing a weak candidate like Lien upon the masses. You watch this with a cold, satisfied detachment. You warned them. You told Lee Teng-hui that you were the only one who could save the party. He chose to destroy the party rather than let you lead it. Now, he has his wish.

A senior aide rushes over. "Governor... Mr. President. The AIT (American Institute in Taiwan) is on the line. They want to congratulate you. And... they want assurances about Cross-Strait stability."

You nod. You are ready. You have always been the most capable administrator on this island. The Americans know it. The Chinese know it. You are not a radical like A-Bian. You are not a puppet like Lien. You are the "Third Way."

You step out onto the stage. The rain has finally stopped, leaving the air crisp and cold. The crowd stretches as far as the eye can see—a sea of orange vests and flags. They chant your name, but it sounds different tonight. It is not the desperate plea of the oppressed; it is the confident roar of the majority.

"My friends!" you shout, your voice booming with the charisma that no other politician in Taiwan can match. "They told you that your vote was wasted! They told you that the polls were fake! They told you that you had to choose between corruption and war!"

The crowd boos at the mention of the other parties.

"But you stood firm!" you continue, pointing into the camera, addressing the nation. "You saw through the tricks! You saw through the 'false reports' from Mayor Ma! You proved that the wisdom of the Taiwanese people cannot be manipulated by a few elites in a back room!"

You pause, letting the applause wash over you. You feel the weight of the moment. With over 40% of the vote, you have a mandate to reshape the political landscape. You will form the People First Party (PFP) not as a splinter group, but as the new center of gravity. You will absorb the KMT's carcass. You will check the DPP's rise.

You look toward the north, toward the mountains. You think of the long, hard road from the "Governor's House" to the Presidential Palace. It was a road paved with betrayal. But tonight, as the confetti falls like orange snow, you know one thing for certain:

The "Old Man" is finished. The "Golden Boy" Ma has tarnished his soul for nothing. And James Soong is the master of the house.

【Old Cat Musings】Back Then, All We Cared About Was Jay Chou's New Album

Published: 2024-X-X | Category: Time Machine | Comments (2310)

The campaign van outside just drove past again, its loudspeaker blaring calls to recall the local legislator—the noise is giving me a headache. My phone keeps dinging; in the Line family chat, my uncle and aunt have once again erupted into an argument over William Lai’s recent "Great Recall" policy, ending with my uncle leaving the group, leaving a dead silence behind.

I turn off my phone, and suddenly, I desperately miss the summer of 2002.

James Soong had just been president for two years. Back then, Taiwan possessed a sense of "stable predictability" that has utterly vanished today.

The NT$60 Drumstick Bento and the Smooth Asphalt

For those of us who lived through the "Orange Eight Years" (2000–2008), the lingering memory isn't about GDP figures, but about the fact that "life was predictable."

I remember my starting salary then—not extravagant, but genuinely "stretching far." Near Taipei Main Station, you could grab a big, crispy fried chicken drumstick bento box for just NT$60, packed full of side dishes. A bubble tea was only NT$25; that was pure, tangible happiness.

People used to complain that Soong was an "administrative control freak" who sweated the details. A popular anecdote claimed that if President Soong saw a single pothole, the Director of Public Works would be ruined the next day.

But did you know? Those were the eight years with the smoothest roads in Taiwan.

I rode my old Kymco scooter from New Taipei to work, and my backside never felt a bump. Unlike now, where riding feels like an off-road race, full of patches and potholes. Public services then had an "invisible reliability"—garbage trucks arrived on the dot, getting a passport didn't require fighting for a number, and the trains were rarely late. The government was like an old-fashioned refrigerator: it hummed a little (Soong's old-school moralizing), but it consistently kept things cool; whatever you put in wouldn't spoil.

In Those Years, We "Nudged" Each Other on MSN

The online world was so much simpler then. No cyber armies, no partisan accounts setting the agenda. We'd get home from work and immediately sign onto MSN, checking if the girl we liked was online.

The biggest arguments weren't about unification vs. independence, or who was selling out Taiwan, but whether Jay Chou's Fantasy was better than Octet; who the handsomest member of F4 was. Politics was truly "boring" back then. Soong's government was like a strict academic dean who standardized everything. News rarely showed legislative brawls.

Because politics didn't steal the show, we had time for life. We had time to queue for Portuguese egg tarts, binge-watch Meteor Garden, and plan to save up for a small apartment in Banqiao within a few years—we genuinely could afford it.

2008: The Vouchers, The Final Comfort

In 2008, the global financial crisis hit, and life suddenly became tough. Even though people voted the PFP out that year and brought in Hsieh Chang-ting, the society remained peaceful during the transition. Soong's figure bowing as he stepped down was just like his eight years in office: dignified, by the book.

The Old Days That Won't Return

I miss the era where politics only took up 5% of life, and the remaining 95% was sheer contentment.

I miss the old Taiwan where the roads were smooth, the bentos were full, and the people were warm.

The Tycoon’s Second Act: Gou’s Retribution and the Perfection of Oligarchy

— TAIPEI

As Terry Gou, founder of Foxconn, former president, and now president-elect, strode onto the stage at Ketagalan Boulevard, even his "spiritual twin," Donald Trump in Washington or Mar-a-Lago, would likely be envious of the sheer scale of this comeback.

Accompanied by his running mate, media mogul Jaw Shaw-kong, the "Golden Boy," Gou declared to his fervent Orange and deep-Blue supporters: "We are taking our country back, and this time, it is forever."

This is more than just an election victory; it is a complete shift in Taiwan's political spectrum towards right-wing populism and corporate oligarchy—a process that began 24 years ago in that fateful millennium but has reached a disturbing climax today.

2016: The Shocking ‘Hostile Takeover’

To understand the current situation, we must look back at 2016. That year was supposed to be the seamless handover to the technocratic, then-Vice President Tsai Ing-wen. Tsai represented the decorum, moderation, and elitism of the establishment.

However, the People First Party (PFP) did not follow the script. The political machine established by James Soong in 2000 was no longer a simple party but a massive platform for distributing patronage and interests. When Gou announced his bid for the PFP nomination and partnered with Wu Den-yih (who was well-versed in local factional operations), he launched a perfect "hostile takeover."

Gou's 2016 campaign strategy mirrored Trump's: he attacked the Ma-Tsai establishment for stagnating the Taiwanese economy, promising to run the country with the iron fist he used at Foxconn. He defeated Tsai, shocking the world.

2020: The Stolen Election?

Gou's first term (2016–2020), however, was full of controversy. He treated the government like a corporate board, declared war on the media, and pushed radical business integration across the strait. This high-pressure rule provoked a backlash, leading to his defeat by the DPP's Cheng Wen-tsan in 2020.

Gou never truly conceded defeat. Over the past four years, he was plotting a long, determined revenge. Utilizing the media empire controlled by Jaw Shaw-kong, he relentlessly attacked the Cheng Wen-tsan administration and fanned fears of "corruption and incompetence."

2024: The Tycoon’s Return and the System’s Ultimate Form

The Gou of 2024 was darker and more radical. If 2016 Gou was a businessman trying to reform the system, 2024 Gou was a revenger vowing to purge the "deep state."

He partnered with Jaw Shaw-kong, and the real confidence behind Gou's victory stemmed from the ghost that traces back to 2000—the deep integration of local interest groups. In the early 2000s, the Soong administration institutionalized local factions, but Gou, the cold CEO, simply bought the entire system.

We saw the full realization of this system: local temples, irrigation associations, and long-term politically affiliated local forces all became Gou's mobilization machinery. This is no longer simple vote-buying; it is a deep-seated "shareholder politics"—where everyone holds a stake in "Gou's Taiwan Inc.," and dissenters are treated as enemies threatening corporate profits.

Conclusion: Asia’s Mar-a-Lago?

Gou's victory signals Taiwan's entry into a new, unpredictable era. He promised "massive purges," pledged to redefine the loyalty of the civil service, and committed to subordinating the Taiwanese economy entirely to efficiency and profit.

For those in Washington worried about a Trump return, Taipei has just offered a vivid preview of how an emerging democracy, under the temptation of a charismatic strongman, is moving step-by-step toward corporate oligarchic rule.

Registration Day Illusion: When Two Decades of Dust Prepare to Burn for Four More Years

Posted by: FortyYearsConfused | November 24, 2023

I. The Prelude: Registration Day and the Endless Cycle

Today is the official registration day for presidential candidates.

On TV, incumbent President Han Kuo-yu walks into the Central Election Commission in that familiar jacket, surrounded by local grandees, corporate sponsors, and the same old faction leaders whose faces never change. The massive 'populist' spectacle—I’ve watched it for four years, and now it looks like a tedious, familiar play.

The PFP victory in the 2000 election opened this long corridor woven from patronage and local connections. From James Soong to Wu Den-yih, and now to the populist Han Kuo-yu, the Pan-Blue camp has governed in various forms for almost twenty years (aside from that brief Su-Hsieh interregnum). Facing this incumbent running for a second term, I feel not choice, but a profound historical inertia.

This nation looks magnificent—the stock market is soaring, and the tech industry is proud—but internally, it resembles an old house hollowed out by termites.

II. The Golden Age We Lost: Discipline under President Chiang

Young people today can't imagine what Taiwan was like in the early nineties. A certain 'discipline' left over from the Chiang Ching-kuo era still lingered.

Back then, civil servants genuinely feared the consequences of corruption. There was less political mudslinging, less standing on ideological sides—only a simple goal: getting the Taiwanese economy airborne. The sheer resolve of President Chiang, that spirit focused on long-term national construction, is the deepest nostalgia for those of us who lived through it. Corruption existed, but it hid in the shadows; now? It sits on the main stage, leading the cheers.

III. The Saboteur: Lee Teng-hui

If there is one starting point for this downfall, I would point unreservedly to Lee Teng-hui.

The technocratic system and national vision painstakingly built by President Chiang were torn apart by his own hands. It was Lee who, to consolidate his power, condoned, even directed, the fusion of local factions with money politics. He turned politics from an ideal of "serving the nation" into the art of "patronage distribution."

IV. Soong's Compromise and the Long Rot

When James Soong won in 2000, we held onto one last hope.

Soong was an excellent administrator. His eight years (2000-2008) indeed boosted administrative efficiency, and he brought the runaway local power bases from the Lee era back under 'systemic management.' But this is his original sin: for the sake of governing stability, he lacked the courage to confront patronage head-on like Chiang Ching-kuo. He chose 'cooperation and co-existence.'

This model was passed down to the PFP successor, Wu Den-yih (2008-2016), and it completely soured. During Wu's eight years, while the economy was stable, the voice of the local factions behind the scenes grew louder, and the nation lost its vitality.

V. Han Kuo-yu: The Populist Carnival

We thought the DPP's Su Tseng-chang and Frank Hsieh would bring change in 2016, and they tried. But four years later, the wave of populism pushed the KMT's Han Kuo-yu to the presidency.

Tragically, behind Han's 'common people' banner are the same old faces. He's not the 'blood-and-iron savior' like President Chiang; he simply knows how to use the simplest slogans to corral the vast local power structure. He is better at political performance than Soong, but he inherits the same 'patronage rules' set during the Lee Teng-hui era.

It is November 24, 2023. When I see those same local bosses—active since the 1990s—donning their 'patriotic' vests to campaign for him, I feel a chill:

We spent twenty years, went through three parties (PFP, DPP, KMT) ruling in succession, and ultimately ended up back where we started. This is not a political cycle; it is the ultimate victory of the 'Grand Local Factional Alliance.'

I don't miss the KMT; I miss the disciplined, hopeful Taiwan with a national vision—the one before Lee Teng-hui unleashed the chaos.

This coming election will only extend this disillusioned history for another four years.

Twilight of the Godfather: Anatomy of the "Orange Dynasty"

The Pacific Observer | By James Kennedy | May 21, 2024

TAIPEI — As the 73-year-old Fu Kun-chi takes the oath of office in the Ching-kuo Hall of the Presidential Office, accepting the Seal of the Republic of China from the aged James Soong, the scene marks not just a transfer of power, but the climax of a political drama spanning a quarter-century.

To outside observers, Taiwan is a democracy: there are periodic elections, a raucous legislature, and relatively free media. Yet, since that history-altering "Soong Landslide" in 2000, Taiwan's political spectrum has been frozen in a specific amber known as the "People First Party (PFP)," with a hardener known as the complex patronage network of "Black Gold."

2000: Original Sin and the Contract

It began on that rainy night in 2000. Contrary to the hopes of idealists, it was not a victory for "clean politics," but a triumph of "resource allocation." As our editorial noted back then: "Soong didn't win because he defeated the KMT; he won because he bought the very foundation upon which the KMT relied."

Soong realized that to maintain long-term rule, he had to weave local factions, irrigation associations, temple systems, and local organized crime into the PFP's "Grand Coalition." This was the famous "Contract of 2000": local forces exchanged ironclad votes for central infrastructure budgets and legal immunity.

2008: Taiwan's "Putin Moment"

lthough our team's strong refutation success

If 2000 was the laying of the foundation, 2008 was the coronation. The Global Financial Crisis devastated Taiwan's economy. Facing soaring unemployment, Soong bypassed bureaucracy to distribute massive cash allowances and consumer vouchers directly to grassroots factions. Economically disastrous, perhaps, but a political masterstroke—cementing his image as a "Messiah" to the underclass.

Riding this wave of populism, the PFP-controlled Legislative Yuan passed controversial constitutional amendments in 2008, citing a "national crisis" to remove presidential term limits. To appease international scrutiny, Soong staged a brilliant "duet," handing the presidency to his loyal deputy, Chang Chao-hsiung. The "Chang Era" was essentially a regency, lasting until Soong returned in 2012. He never left again—until yesterday.

The Capillaries of Patronage

Why, for 24 years, could neither the drained KMT nor the marginalized DPP shake the PFP's rule? The answer lies in Soong's "Electoral Authoritarianism."

The playing field is severely tilted. In rural central and southern Taiwan, if you want a road paved or a temple built, the only path is through the PFP's "Vote Captains" (Zhuang Jiao). This structure created a stable oligarchy. A few major families control media, construction, and finance. This is the so-called "Black Gold"—no longer back-alley deals, but the open governance model of the Grand Hotel.

2024: The Long Night Begins

Now, as Soong retires at 82, his chosen successor makes everyone gasp. Fu Kun-chi, the "King of Hualien," represents the naked face of Black Gold politics. If Soong wore the Confucian cloak of "diligent governance," Fu represents the raw exercise of power.

Taiwan still has elections. But behind the ballot box, the "Orange Black Gold Empire" built of cement, cash, favors, and intimidation seems more indestructible than any democratic institution. For Taiwan's democracy, this is not just the twilight of the Godfather; it may be the beginning of a long night.

Author SkyWalker2024 (The Wanderer) Board Gossiping
Title [Query] Seriously, what was life like during Governor Soong's eight years?
Time Wed Mar 13 22:15:30 2024

Title says it all.

I was born in 2000, and my impression of James Soong is only from history class about the "Orange PFP Administration."
When I became aware of politics, it was already Tsai Ing-wen's second term, then Eric Chu beat William Lai in 2020,
and now Chu is getting re-inaugurated; it feels like the KMT is set for an eternal rule.

I overheard my parents discussing Eric Chu's cabinet list, and my dad sighed and said:
"The eight years under Old Soong (2000-2008) were more stable; everyone now is too slick."

I'm really curious, what was Taiwan actually like during Soong's presidency?
I heard that after Wu Den-yih took over in 2008, things went downhill, which is why Tsai Ing-wen was able to snag the win in 2012.
But was Soong himself really that legendary during his eight years?
Any boomers who lived through that era please share your stories?

I heard civil servants used to tremble when they saw Soong?
I heard there was no Blue-Green infighting, only "Soong's Will"?

Any insider gossip?

【Facebook Time Machine: On the Eve of the 2024 Election】

Post by 8thGenQuestion
Just now · 🌍

Seeing the news analyzing this election (William Lai, Hou Yu-ih, Ko Wen-je tri-polar contest), some say the current political chaos stems from the legacy of the "PFP Eight Years." I'm completely confused.

My only impression of James Soong is that he's very old. What was the 2000-2008 era actually like? Everyone says it was stable, with low prices, but why did the PFP eventually become marginalized? Seeking answers!

📌 Era Background at a Glance:

  • 2000-2008: James Soong (PFP) served as President (successfully re-elected in 2004, defeating Hsieh Chang-ting).
  • 2008: Hit by the global financial crisis, the PFP failed to secure a third term; Ma Ying-jeou (KMT) was elected.
  • 2008-2016: KMT in power.
  • 2016-2024: Su Tseng-chang (DPP) in power, about to step down after two terms.

#PFP #JamesSoong #TearsOfTheEra #NoMeritNoFault

DeepBlue66 Those eight years were the calmest time for Taiwan! His administrative ability was top-notch; roads were smooth and lights were on. With the KMT's help in the legislature, administrative efficiency was super high. The PFP's collapse wasn't Soong's fault; it was the 2008 global financial crisis. KMT's Ma Ying-jeou just took over that mess and governed until 2016.
Like·Reply·2 hours ago
TaiwanGoGreen Don't kid yourself! Those eight years were called 'Stability in Regression'! Soong focused only on fixing roads and dared not touch the structural problems of local factions; he just drove them under the table, turning them into hidden black gold. He made no major reforms, which is why the subsequent KMT rule was so stagnant. Su Tseng-chang only began pushing for reform after taking over!
Like·Reply·1 hour ago
OrangeIsTheNewBlue Alas, I was part of the Orange Army back then. Young people only cared about Jay Chou's new album; nobody was arguing about politics. President Soong's biggest mistake was not grooming a successor. Once he stepped down, the PFP lost its voice and was eventually absorbed by the KMT, only to be marginalized in the legislature.
Like·Reply·45 minutes ago
MiddleRoadWanderer Objectively, the Soong era was no merit, no fault. Critical issues like land, pension, and education reform were all untouched. Those eight years were wasted on 'stability.' The current fierce debates are the price we're paying for that era's 'political truce.'
Like·Reply·30 minutes ago

The Eye of the Needle

"We walked through the fire, and though we are singed, we are still standing."

The rain outside the "New Taiwanese Service Team" headquarters has finally ceased, leaving the Taipei night cool and damp. Inside, the noise is deafening, but it is a different kind of noise than the one you dreamed of months ago. It is not the seamless, rolling thunder of a landslide. It is the jagged, hysterical relief of a near-death experience. The air is thick with the smell of sweat, wet wool, and the adrenaline of a battle that went down to the final trench.

You, James Soong, lean against the heavy oak desk in your private office, away from the prying eyes of the cameras. You look at the final tally on the small CRT monitor. ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%. You have won. You are the President-elect. But the number tells a story of a brutal war of attrition.

It was not the 45% coronation you hoped for in the heady days of autumn. The KMT's machine, wounded as it was, still managed to claw back some of the "Iron Votes." The "Fake Polls" released by Ma Ying-jeou in the final days did their damage, frightening the wavering centrists into returning to the fold. And Chen Shui-bian... the lawyer from Tainan fought like a demon, mobilizing the south in a wave of green that nearly swallowed the island.

But nearly is not enough. You held the line.

Chang Chao-hsiung, your running mate, sits in the armchair, looking exhausted. He cleans his glasses slowly, his hands trembling slightly. "It was the Middle Path," he says quietly. "It was narrow, Governor. Much narrower than we thought. But we walked it. The people rejected the extremes, even if they hesitated until the very last second."

You nod. You have defeated the "Two Party System." You have broken the stranglehold of the establishment. But you are also a minority president. You look at the map—it is a patchwork quilt. You won the critical battlegrounds in Taichung and the North, but the margins were tight. You are not an Emperor tonight; you are a Survivor.

Chen Wan-shui walks in, holding a cup of warm tea. She looks at you with eyes that have seen too much mudslinging, too many insults, too many sleepless nights. The "Chung Hsing Bills" scandal was meant to kill you. The accusations of betrayal were meant to bury you. Yet here you are. She places the tea in your hand. "They couldn't stop you, Chu-yu," she whispers. "They threw the entire state apparatus at you, and you still beat them. That is the victory. Not the number, but the fact that you are here at all."

The television screen shows the chaos at the KMT headquarters. It is a riot. The "Old Guard" is being purged by the angry mob. Lee Teng-hui is being demonized by his own party members. You feel a cold, grim satisfaction. The man who tried to destroy you has inadvertently destroyed his own creation. By forcing you out, he split the party, and in doing so, he handed the country to the one man he feared most. The irony is Shakespearean.

But the challenges ahead are mountainous. You have no party infrastructure in the legislature. You will face a hostile DPP opposition that controls the streets of the south, and a bitter KMT remnant that views you as a traitor. You will have to build a "Supra-party Government" (全民政府) from scratch. You will have to negotiate with Beijing while calming Washington.

You straighten your tie. The orange tie that has become the symbol of a movement. It is time to go out there. It is time to tell the people that the "Third Way" is not just a slogan, but a reality.

You step out onto the balcony. The crowd erupts. It is a sea of orange flags, wet with rain but waving defiantly. They chant your name, "Song Zongtong! Song Zongtong!" The sound washes away the fatigue. For this moment, the percentage doesn't matter. The mandate is real because the people are here.

"My fellow Taiwanese!" you shout, your voice cracking with emotion. "We have arrived!"

The crowd roars back.

"The road was long!" you continue, gripping the podium. "The wind was against us! The rain was against us! The powers that be were against us! But the people... the people were with us!"

You look out over the city of Taipei. The lights of the Presidential Palace glow in the distance. It will be your office tomorrow. It will be a lonely office, beset by enemies on all sides. But tonight, you are the man who beat the system. You are the independent who became King.

As the confetti falls, you catch the eye of a young volunteer in the front row, crying tears of joy. You realize that to these people, ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}% is not a statistic. It is a revolution. You have threaded the needle. Now, you must weave the fabric of a new nation.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/8eaca05c-2dd8-4919-838a-5e2f6ee17142.jpg?v=1765967032023"})]); } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] >= 35 && quickstats[1] <= 40 && e.PoliticalReformPromise <= -4) { // Ending E: Zero Capital (PR < 1 and BGC < 1) - The Constitutional Stagnation Timeline (Content from original Block G) e.pages.push(`

ISLAND VIEWPOINT

Independent Analysis for a Sovereign Taiwan

【Deep Dive】The "Undead" on Yangmingshan: Lai Ching-te's Victory and the Constitutional Nightmare Left by James Soong

—Why is Taiwan in 2024 Still Paying the Price for the "Dual-Parliament" System?

By Chen Yi-chi (Senior Political Commentator) | January 16, 2024

When Mr. Lai Ching-te announced his commitment to "launch a new round of constitutional review" in his victory speech last night, many veteran reporters could only force a wry smile. We heard that exact promise when Su Tseng-chang won in 2016, when Ma Ying-jeou won in 2008, and even during James Soong's nail-biting 0.5% victory over Frank Hsieh in 2004.

Yet, the harsh reality remains: as of 2024, the **National Assembly (NA)**, the so-called "constitutional appendix," still occupies the Chung-Shan Building on Yangmingshan, fighting the Legislative Yuan in the valley below for legislative and constitutional amendment powers.

I. 2000-2008: Soong's Inaction and the Lost Constitutional Moment

The root of this catastrophe lies in the political transition of 2000, which lacked decisiveness. James Soong, winning with less than 40% of the vote, established a weak government. Faced with an opposition-controlled legislature, the "Super Governor" chose the path of least resistance: **administrative authoritarianism and constitutional freezing**.

Soong was essentially a brilliant technocrat of the old era. He had zero interest in democratic deepening and actively avoided constitutional reform. Throughout his eight years in office (especially after his narrow 2004 re-election win against Hsieh), he refused calls to abolish the National Assembly, even leveraging the NA to check the DPP-led Legislative Yuan.

He took "maintaining the status quo" to its extreme, allowing Taiwan to miss the critical constitutional moment that should have occurred around 2005. He thought he was ensuring stability, but he was merely postponing a constitutional bomb indefinitely.

II. From "Perpetual Legislators" to "Local Warlords' Retirement Home"

Some argue the current National Assembly is no longer composed of the old "thieves" who fled China. Yes, after years of indirect elections, the current NA members are primarily local Taiwanese. But this has only created a greater disaster.

During the terms of Ma Ying-jeou (2008-2016) and Su Tseng-chang (2016-2024), the National Assembly gradually transformed into a **"retirement home"** for vested interests. Local faction leaders and former politicians who failed to secure Legislative Yuan seats flock to the NA. They wield powers of constitutional review, personnel confirmation, and frequently threaten presidential impeachment or budget freezes, creating an absurd **"Dual-Parliament Disorder."**

This duplication of power has severely crippled Taiwan's legislative efficiency, leaving judicial interpretation constantly contested between the NA and the Council of Grand Justices. In 2024, we elected Lai Ching-te, yet we must still financially support these "constitutional redundancies" who meet on Yangmingshan to argue and disrupt.

III. Soong's Historical Legacy: A Giant of Efficiency, A Dwarf of Reform

Looking back over the past twenty-four years, James Soong has been hailed by the Pan-Blue camp as the "God of Administrative Efficiency." But from a historical perspective, he is arguably **the greatest culprit in the stagnation of Taiwan's democracy**.

He used eight years of stellar administrative efficiency to mask the rot of the constitutional structure. He taught the Taiwanese people to believe that as long as the president is competent, it doesn't matter if the constitution is flawed. The result is that when the strongman left, the system he preserved became a crippling, dysfunctional zombie.

Today, as President Lai Ching-te walks into the Presidential Office, he faces not only cross-strait pressure but also the constitutional monster—bloated and unmanageable—that Soong Chu-yu personally ensured survived. Abolish the National Assembly? Given the complex entanglement of KMT, DPP, TPP, and the NA's own self-interest, this seems an impossible task.

This is Soong's true legacy to Taiwan: a democracy that can never fully mature, and a National Assembly that never dies.

Author Reporter (NetizenJournalist) Board Gossiping
Title [NEWS] James Soong Approved for Medical Parole, Leaving Prison This Afternoon
Time Mon Jan  5 15:32:10 2015

1. Media Source:
CNA

2. Complete News Title:
James Soong Approved for Medical Parole, Leaving Taichung Prison This Afternoon

3. Complete News Content:

(Taichung, 5th Jan) Former President James Soong, who was involved in the Hsing Piao Case, the Presidential State Affairs Fund Scandal, and multiple public works corruption cases, was arrested by the Special Investigation Unit (SIU) in 2008 and sentenced to 20 years. Having served over 6 years, the Ministry of Justice Agency of Corrections today approved Soong's application for medical parole, citing complex health issues that, while not immediately life-threatening, cannot be properly treated in the prison environment.

During Soong's 2000-2008 administration, although he promoted many infrastructure projects, the "Second Hsing Piao Storm" and "Gravel Case" involving collusion with local factions caused a massive outcry. Following the 2008 political transition, the succeeding DPP President Frank Hsieh ordered a thorough investigation, making Soong the first former President of the Republic of China to be imprisoned.

Current President Ma Ying-jeou stated he respects the Ministry of Justice's professional judgment and hopes the public views the issue from a human rights perspective, calling for reconciliation across the political spectrum. People First Party Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung is expected to lead supporters to greet Soong at Taichung Prison this afternoon.

Soong is expected to leave the prison at 3:30 PM and return home to Taipei for recuperation.

4. Notes:
He's out.

FORMOSA INSIGHT
January 8, 2020

[Editorial] The Undying "Machine": Tracing Han Kuo-yu's Army Back to the Soong Era

In the deafening roar of Han Kuo-yu's rallies, we hear the echoes of the Lee Teng-hui and Soong Chu-yu era—a network of local factions that never truly died. This structural inertia now threatens to reshape Taiwan's democracy.

By Lin Cheng-wei (Political Analyst)

As the 2020 presidential election enters its final countdown, the battle between President Su Tseng-chang (DPP) and Mayor Han Kuo-yu (KMT) transcends mere policy disagreements. A deep structural phenomenon is unfolding beneath the surface: the massive, coordinated mobilization of Taiwan's traditional local factions. This is not simply grassroots enthusiasm; it is the calculated deployment of a political machine established decades ago. The Han campaign's ability to summon crowds and resources hinges entirely on these networks, illustrating that the core DNA of Taiwanese politics remains captive to patronage and localized power dynamics.

The Legacy of the "Super Governor": Institutionalizing Patronage (2000-2008)

When James Soong won the presidency in 2000 with a mere plurality (35-40%), his political survival depended entirely on co-opting the highly efficient, patronage-driven machine left by Lee Teng-hui. Instead of dismantling the "Black Gold" structure he once criticized, Soong, the ultimate pragmatist, chose to perfect it. He systematically funneled state resources—chiefly through infrastructure contracts, agricultural subsidies, and local government appointments—to secure the loyalty of key families. This created a political model we might call **"Grey Efficiency,"** where administrative competence was a byproduct of factional cooperation: the factions received construction contracts (e.g., the Hsieh family in Changhua), and in return, guaranteed smooth policy implementation and vote mobilization. Soong's government turned corruption from an erratic threat into a predictable, functional cost of governance, thus preserving the machine's essential operational capability long after the People First Party itself began to fade into obscurity.

The Failed Reforms of the Ma Era (2008-2016)

When the KMT reclaimed power under Ma Ying-jeou, he attempted to distance the party from the factions, promoting a "clean and fresh" governance brand aimed at appealing to the urban middle class. However, Ma's reforms were fundamentally administrative, not structural. His legalistic approach alienated the KMT's own old guard and the powerful local families who expected continued patronage as their right. Crucially, Ma failed to touch the factions' deep economic roots—their control over utilities, agricultural associations, and local transportation—allowing their wealth and influence to remain intact. By prioritizing a "clean" central government while ignoring the festering local substructure, Ma merely pushed the "Machine" into temporary hibernation. It remained fully charged, dormant, and waiting for a leader who understood the transactional nature of local power.

Han Kuo-yu: The Avatar of the Old System (2020)

Enter Han Kuo-yu. Unlike the aloof and academic Ma, Han possesses the "common touch" and populist language that resonate deeply with the factional base. His 2020 campaign, far from being a grassroots innovation, is the full-scale **resurrection of the structural legacy** preserved by Soong. The muscle behind the campaign is palpable: the Chang faction in Yunlin (mobilizing vast agrarian networks), the Yen clan in Taichung (delivering critical legislative seats and logistical support), and the coordinated efforts of power brokers across the south, like the Su family in Pingtung. Han provides the charismatic veneer, but the campaign's massive rally logistics—the buses, the resources, the localized voter lists—are a direct payoff from the unreformed patronage system that James Soong ensured survived his own tenure. Han is, in essence, the modern Avatar of Soong-style politics.

Conclusion: The Structural Stagnation

If Han Kuo-yu wins on Saturday, it will underscore a profound failure in Taiwan's democratic development. It will confirm that despite the political upheaval of the 2000 split and the subsequent rotations, the constitutional and political architecture remains fundamentally unreformed. The moment of truth came during the Soong presidency; his decision to prioritize short-term stability and "Grey Efficiency" over structural clean-up is the ultimate reason why the local faction machine—that powerful, enduring entity—survived Ma's efforts to dismantle it and is now ready to reclaim the national reins under Han. The "Soong Chu-yu Era" never truly ended; it merely found a new, populist host body to continue its reign as the unacknowledged kingmaker of Taiwan.

`); // 圖片代碼 e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/20200114102205-ae387a82.jpg'})]); // 音樂代碼 if (songChange != 1) { songChange = 1 const lienWin = new Playlist(); const lienWinSong50 = new Song( "Lonely tree,lonely bird", "Wu Bai", "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/1d/Lonely_Tree%2C_Lonely_Bird.jpg", "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/%E4%BC%8D%E4%BD%B0%20Wu%20Bai%26China%20Blue%E3%80%90%E6%A8%B9%E6%9E%9D%E5%AD%A4%E9%B3%A5%20Lonely%20tree%2Clonely%20bird%E3%80%91Official%20Music%20Video%20-%20%E6%BB%BE%E7%9F%B3%E5%94%B1%E7%89%87%20ROCK%20RECORDS%20(youtube).mp3?v=1764141005257" ); lienWin.addSong(lienWinSong50,0); changePlaylist(lienWin); } } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] >= 35 && quickstats[1] <= 40 && e.PoliticalReformPromise >= -2 && e.PoliticalReformPromise <= -1) { // HTML Content: Historical table based on the new timeline (Scenario 22 - PFP start, mixed later, ending in 2024). Threads Feed (August 2025)

@Commuter_4eva 2h ago
+1. My only memory is the HSR (High-Speed Rail) finally getting sorted, and honestly, the roads were butter-smooth around 2005. Seems like the Premiers back then were just competing on who could tighten the screws best. No major scandals, but zero dreams either.
@ApathyMaster 1h ago
It was... boring AF. Back then, everyone only cared if the electronics industry was making money; who cared what the Legislature was fighting about? He was a **"Civil Servant President,"** running the country like one giant Executive Yuan. After he stepped down in '08, he disappeared entirely—no desire to run for office again.
@Reformer_Wannabe [highly disputed] 1h ago
He was a political opportunist! Took the reins but didn't dare push any reform or touch cross-strait issues—just maintained the status quo. His **"zero-capital"** governing style made Taiwan miss its golden age of reform. Then Ma took over, and things got even worse.
@OldSchool_PFP_Fan 50m ago
Chill out, everyone. Soong's eight years were Taiwan's most stable time, alright? Look at Hsiao Bi-khim's government now—they fight over the Legislature every day. Back then, the economy quietly grew, stocks were steady, no ideological fighting. He just focused on getting things done. His only flaw was not grooming anyone for the PFP.

`); // 沿用圖片 e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/ROCPE.jpg?v=1764174039638'})]); exclusive_action_executed = true; } // 5. 結局 (中度改革) - PRP = 1 或 2：安靜的妥協 (Content from original Block #5) if(!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] >= 35 && quickstats[1] <= 40 && e.PoliticalReformPromise >= 1 && e.PoliticalReformPromise <= 2) { // HTML Content: Online Memoir - The Quiet Soong Years vs. Today's World e.pages.push(`

Reflections from the Millennium: The Quiet Soong Years and My Family's Stability

By Old Lin (75) | November 25, 2020

It's been six years since I fully retired, and the world is noisier than ever. President Cheng Wen-tsan's administration is constantly battling social groups and the opposition; every day brings some new high-stakes protest or policy fight. It makes me reflect on the time when things felt—well, **stable**.

I remember the 2000 election day vividly. My wife and I stayed up late, tense, watching the results roll in. When James Soong won by a narrow margin, there was a sense of relief, a feeling that finally, the "Super Governor" would just run the country like a large city—efficiently. And in many ways, he did. His first term, especially, was defined by an almost boring competence. The roads were suddenly smooth. The high-speed rail project, which had been stalled by constant squabbles, finally got moving. For us middle-aged workers, life simply continued; our annual raises were small but steady, and our son graduated university without issue.

The Scare of '04 and the Quiet Compromise

The biggest political drama was the 2004 re-election. Soong faced a terrifying combined ticket from Frank Hsieh (DPP) and Lien Chan (KMT). It was an alliance built on pure fear of Soong's moderate, pragmatic centrist hold. We almost lost him. When he pulled through with just a two-point lead, there was a collective national sigh. In his second term, the only major political change was the successful freezing of the National Assembly—a huge deal on paper, but something most people barely noticed in their daily lives. The constitutional power of the Presidency remained vast, and Soong, the powerful administrator, simply filled the vacuum.

They say Soong didn't enact 'deep' reform, that he just kept the surface clean. Maybe so. But for me, the mid-2000s were when I finally paid off the mortgage. My daughter bought her first apartment in Taoyuan. When the government is stable and competent, people can focus on their own quiet lives. That was Soong's real legacy: making the government boring enough for us to thrive.

We saw less corruption on the front pages, and the economy kept ticking. Soong never touched the deep structural problems, the legislative gridlock remained, and the party system didn't fundamentally change—which is perhaps why the PFP never built a lasting base. But for those eight years, the focus was on tangible results: bridges, logistics, and GDP numbers. It was a golden age of administration, if not of democratic revolution.

2020: The Change of Pace

Now, we have President Cheng Wen-tsan (DPP). He's modern, tech-savvy, and focuses intensely on social justice and digital infrastructure. It's necessary work, but the constant ideological friction is exhausting. Every policy change, from labor laws to energy policy, is met with massive rallies and social media wars. My grandchildren are politically active and spend hours arguing online. I'm glad they care, but I confess I miss the quiet stability of the Soong years, when the biggest headline was usually about a new highway opening, not a constitutional crisis. Cheng is pushing hard for change, but sometimes, an old man just wishes the roads were smooth and the TV news wasn't quite so loud.

`); // 图片代码 e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/jpg_00_01_07_75_cca220002-hp-199812110309000000l-0001-i.jpg?v=1764152272869'})]); // 音乐代码 if (songChange != 1) { songChange = 1 const lienWin = new Playlist(); const lienWinSong50 = new Song( "The Story of Time", "Luo Da-you", "https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/Rz_G9lNJLEg-xdLPHXT6S12mKjYKcx30Fuljg5tN8whCz0bWmZqR2Nl37LSWTTFK73YwbK9Sz6ZjRmQ", "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/%E5%85%89%E9%99%B0%E7%9A%84%E6%95%85%E4%BA%8B%20(2008%E6%96%B0%E7%89%88)%20-%E7%89%87%E9%A0%AD%E6%9B%B2%20-%20%E7%BE%85%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%91%20(youtube).mp3?v=1764146873800" ); lienWin.addSong(lienWinSong50,0); changePlaylist(lienWin); } } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] >= 35 && quickstats[1] <= 40 && e.PoliticalReformPromise >= 1 && e.PoliticalReformPromise <= 2) { // HTML Content: Historical table based on the new timeline (Scenario 11 - PFP -> KMT -> KMT -> DPP, moderate reform). POLITICS May 21, 2024 | Formosa News Network

Legislative Deadlock: Lai Administration's First Budget Bill Hangs on the "Orange Trio"

(Taipei) The honeymoon period for newly inaugurated President Lai Ching-te (DPP) appears to be over before it began. In the Legislative Yuan today, the KMT caucus, holding a plurality but not a majority, announced a full boycott of the Cabinet's infrastructure budget. With the DPP also falling short of a majority, all eyes have once again turned to the smallest caucus in the chamber: the People First Party (PFP).

Led by veteran legislator Huang Shan-shan, the PFP currently holds only 3 seats—a far cry from its glory days as the ruling party under President James Soong (2000-2008). Yet, in this fractured parliament, these three "Orange votes" have become the kingmakers.

"We will not blindly support the DPP, nor will we blindly follow the KMT's obstructionism," Huang Shan-shan told reporters this morning. "We will adhere to the spirit of 'Rational Professionalism' championed by former President Soong."

Analysis: The Shadow of the "Lonely President"
The current gridlock is eerily reminiscent of the Soong era. From 2000 to 2008, President Soong, elected with a weak mandate (under 40%), faced relentless boycotts from both major parties. While he successfully froze the National Assembly and established administrative neutrality norms, his refusal to engage in factional horse-trading meant his grander structural reforms often died in the legislature. He left office with a clean reputation but a hollowed-out party structure, leading to the PFP's rapid decline into a micro-party post-2008.

Now, decades later, the PFP remains the last flicker of that "Third Way" ideal, squeezed between the Blue and Green giants.

Top Comments

TaipeiRider: The KMT is just obstructing Taiwan's progress! PFP better vote with the native land!
ROC_Supporter: Lai is a dictator. Huang Shan-shan, don't forget your roots! Block the budget!
Bystander88: Seriously, I'm sick of this 51:49 legislature every single term. This country is structurally incapable of passing major bills.
Moneyball: PFP is a business now, not a party. They're just selling their 3 votes to the highest bidder/best deal on amendments. It's pathetic.
Nostalgia2000 (Top Fan): Looking at this mess, I really miss the Soong era. People say he failed because he didn't control the legislature, but he was the only one who truly tried to fix the system without selling out to factions.

If his "Grand Constitutional Reform" hadn't been blocked by the KMT and DPP back in 2002, we wouldn't have this dysfunctional gridlock today. He was a good president, just born in the wrong time. Taiwan missed its chance.
Reformer_Fail: Soong was too clean for the dirty game. He needed to make alliances, even if they were distasteful, to push his agenda. Idealism doesn't pass bills in the Legislative Yuan.
LegislatorWatch: At least Huang Shan-shan is professional and transparent about her caucus's conditions. She's the only adult in the room, even if she only represents 3 votes.
