The Savior of the Republic

"They called me a traitor. They called me a spoiler. Tonight, history calls me the Victor."

The noise outside the "New Taiwanese Service Team" headquarters is not just cheering; it is the sound of a cliff edge being avoided. The air smells of rain and firecrackers, but underneath it all, there is the distinct, metallic scent of vindication.

You, James Soong, stand before the full-length mirror in your private office. You straighten your orange tie—the color that has redefined the political spectrum of Taiwan. You look into your own eyes and allow yourself a moment of pure, unadulterated satisfaction. You have done the impossible.

The numbers on the screen tell a story that political scientists will study for decades. You have won the presidency with ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%. It is not a landslide. It is a plurality, a mandate carved out of granite with your bare hands. But the sweeter victory lies in the rest of the tally.

Lien Chan is Second. Chen Shui-bian is Third.

You let out a breath you feel you’ve been holding since you were expelled from the KMT. "We didn't just win, Wan-shui," you whisper to the reflection. "We killed the nightmare."

Chen Wan-shui, your wife, sits on the sofa, her hands resting on her lap. She looks exhausted but relieved. The "Sister Wan-shui" that the public adores has been your shield against the vicious attacks from the KMT machine. She smiles at you. "You stopped the war, Chu-yu. That’s what matters. The people were scared of A-Bian. They realized in the end that only you could keep the peace."

She is right. The "Dump-Bian" (棄扁) effect was real. The fear of independence, the fear of Chinese missiles, the fear of the unknown—it drove the voters away from the DPP. But they didn't run back to the incompetent arms of Lien Chan; they ran to you. You successfully positioned yourself as the only adult in the room—the man who could talk to Beijing, the man who could manage the economy, the man who respected the ROC constitution.

Chang Chao-hsiung, your vice-president, walks in with a bottle of Kaoliang wine. "The KMT headquarters is in chaos," he reports, pouring two glasses. "They are calling for Lee Teng-hui's head. They know that if they had just nominated you, the Pan-Blue camp would have 70% of the vote today. Lee destroyed his own party to stop you, and he failed."

You take the glass. You think of Lee Teng-hui sitting in the Presidential Palace. The "Godfather." The man who treated you like a son and then tried to strangle your career in the crib. The "Chung Hsing Bills" scandal was his dagger. He twisted it and twisted it, trying to bleed you dry. But he underestimated the gratitude of the Taiwanese people. He underestimated the "Governor Soong" who visited every village, who held the hands of the farmers, who ate rice with the fishermen.

"Let him watch," you say coldly. "Let him watch as the 'Mainlander' he despised takes his seat."

But the victory is complex. With Lien Chan coming in second, the KMT machine is wounded but not dead. You are a minority president. You will have to govern a country where the legislature is still controlled by the party you just humiliated. You will have to unite the "Pan-Blue" forces. You will have to absorb the KMT, not destroy it. The DPP, pushed to third place, will radicalize in the streets, but for now, they are irrelevant. The "Green Terror" has been averted.

You step out toward the balcony. The roar of the crowd hits you. "Song Zongtong! Song Zongtong!"

You look out at the sea of Orange. You see the faces of the veterans, the civil servants, the middle-class families who just wanted stability. They saved you. And you saved them.

"My friends!" you shout, your voice booming with the authority of a man born to rule. "Tonight, the Republic of China stands tall!"

The crowd erupts.

"They told you that you had to choose between corruption and war! They told you that a vote for Soong was a wasted vote! But you knew the truth! You knew that the Third Way is the only way!"

You raise your fist. You feel the weight of the office settling onto your shoulders. It is heavy, yes. But you are James Soong. You have been preparing for this burden your entire life.

The KMT is broken. The DPP is marginalized. The Sun has set on the old era, and tomorrow, it rises on the Era of Soong.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/1c5cc27a-0bc4-4c83-9b37-1cfe8dbd5f41.jpg?v=1765967376458"})]); } if(!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] < 35 && aa[1].candidate === 68) { // --- English Content (High School History Class Simulation) --- const ENDING_HTML = `

【2025 Taiwan History Class】The Blank Page: Soong Chu-yu's "Coup-Style" Four Years

Mr. Chen (History)

"Students, looking at the 2000 election results, we must understand the core issue: this was the direct result of the split within the KMT during Lee Teng-hui’s late term. Soong Chu-yu narrowly won Lien Chan, securing less than 35% of the vote. His four-year term was characterized by continuous administrative paralysis. The reason the textbook barely covers it is precisely because no substantive policies or institutions were established during those four years."

Xiao Hua (11th Grade)

"Mr. Chen, since Lien Chan and the KMT were completely hostile to Soong, and Soong was expelled from the party, he faced opposition from both the KMT and the DPP. So how was he still able to win the 2000 election? Where did that victory come from?"

Mr. Chen (History)

"That’s an excellent question! Soong’s victory came from the personal charisma and reputation for administrative efficiency he built during his governorship. The public at the time was tired of the KMT establishment's power struggles. Soong’s pragmatic image temporarily transcended party loyalty. His votes were cast by citizens disappointed with the old KMT system, essentially voting for a personal brand with a reformist image, not the PFP as a new party."

Xiao An (11th Grade)

"But Mr. Chen, Soong was famous for his efficiency. Why couldn't his administrative skills be put to use? He had the power to appoint the Premier, right?"

Mr. Chen (History)

"Xiao An hit the nail on the head. Soong’s administrative skills were useless against the Legislative Yuan. Lien Chan’s KMT consistently viewed Soong as a traitor, and their goal wasn't to supervise, but to oust him. They launched a four-year political war: budget proposals were constantly shelved, key personnel nominations were rejected, and no-confidence motions were frequently threatened. Soong had no political tools to fulfill his promises. His four years were spent primarily fending off malicious legislative boycotts."

Siqi (11th Grade)

"What about the PFP itself? As the ruling party, didn't they try to build up strength against the KMT? Or did they just fade away?"

Mr. Chen (History)

"The PFP was effectively Soong Chu-yu's personal party. His victory was built on charisma, lacking robust grassroots organization. Once he failed to deliver on promises, and the KMT successfully framed him in the media and locally as the chief cause of national chaos, the PFP rapidly withered. The KMT successfully pinned the responsibility for the party split entirely on Soong. Four years later, when Lien Chan challenged Soong under a unified banner, the public sentiment was clear: Enough, we need stability. This was Soong’s political tragedy."

Xiao An (11th Grade)

"So, he basically had no real impact on Taiwan's political process. He was just a small, chaotic four-year interlude between long KMT administrations. Lien Chan defeated him in 2004, and the KMT ruled stably for another eight years (until 2012), handed power to Wang Jin-pyng (2012-2016), and was only defeated by the DPP's Su Tseng-chang in 2016. Soong is truly forgotten by history?"

Mr. Chen (History)

"Exactly. The KMT successfully branded Soong's four years as a national crisis. When you study the political history from the late 1990s to the 2020s, you will find: the textbook details Lee Teng-hui's democratization, Lien/Wang's stabilization period, and Su/Lai's policy establishment. But Soong's presidency remains a brief, messy transition within the long KMT rule that failed to pass the parliamentary test. His chapter in history is naturally thin."
`; e.pages.push(ENDING_HTML); // Setting image: A blurred photo of Soong blocked by protest signs in the Legislative Yuan e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/1901710_1.jpg?v=1764152473742'})]); if (songChange != 1) { songChange = 1 const lienWin = new Playlist(); const lienWinSong50 = new Song( "Forgotten Time", "Tsai Chin", "https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/AiQ8afcJriHPeSEiLWwnKK-flofR1zdwYSET0-AjTsL__SXM_B3wKu2yCpLILqwmhIfBMaiGPKE0w7mLQA", "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/%E8%94%A1%E7%90%B4%20Tsai%20Chin%20-%20%E8%A2%AB%E9%81%BA%E5%BF%98%E7%9A%84%E6%99%82%E5%85%89%20(%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%AE%8C%E6%95%B4%E7%89%88MV)%20-%20Timeless%20Music%20(youtube).mp3?v=1764151389446" ); lienWin.addSong(lienWinSong50,0); changePlaylist(lienWin); } } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] < 35 && aa[1].candidate === 68) { // HTML Content: Historical table based on the new timeline (Scenario 13 - PFP -> KMT -> KMT -> DPP, low approval). Ending G: Extreme Turmoil/Legitimacy Crisis // Condition: Soong wins (PK 69) with PV < 35%, and Chen Shui-bian (PK 67) is second if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] < 35 && aa[1].candidate === 67) { e.pages.push(`

The Hollow Crown

"I have won the throne, but the kingdom is burning. The dragon has been slain, but the tiger is waiting at the gate."

The cheering outside the "New Taiwanese Service Team" headquarters on Ren'ai Road is loud, but to your ears, it sounds thin. It lacks the deep, resonant bass of a landslide. It is the high-pitched, hysterical relief of a man who has just walked across a tightrope over a canyon and collapsed on the other side.

You, James Soong, stand alone in the washroom attached to your office. You splash cold water on your face. You look at yourself in the mirror. The "Governor." The "Commander." And now... the President.

But the numbers on the television screen in the other room are burned into your mind, cold and unforgiving. You have secured victory with ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}% of the vote. It is enough to win under the First-Past-The-Post system, but it is not enough to silence the wolves. In any decent democracy, this would be a runoff. In Taiwan, it is a verdict.

Chen Shui-bian is right behind you. The difference is agonizingly small. The "Son of Taiwan" surged in the final weeks, swallowing the south whole, mobilizing a Green tide that nearly breached the seawall. He didn't lose because he was unpopular; he lost because the "Blue" vote—split as it was—was just barely larger than the "Green" vote. He is not a defeated candidate; he is the leader of a government-in-waiting, controlling nearly 35% of the population, armed with passion and grievance.

And Lien Chan? He is finished. A distant third. The KMT machine, with its billions of dollars and century of history, has collapsed into irrelevance. This gives you a grim satisfaction, but also a strategic headache. You have destroyed the party that birthed you, but now you must govern its ruins.

Chen Wan-shui enters the room. She moves quietly, sensing your mood. She doesn't offer empty congratulations. She hands you a fresh towel. "It’s going to be hard, Chu-yu," she says softly. "Harder than the campaign. Half the country thinks you stole it. The other half thinks you are a traitor to the party."

You wipe your face. "I know," you reply. "A-Bian won't concede. Not in his heart. He will take to the streets. He will say that a President with 34% of the vote has no mandate."

You walk back into the main office. Chang Chao-hsiung, your Vice President-elect, is on the phone with the Americans. He looks pale. "The AIT is asking about the protests in Kaohsiung," Chang whispers, covering the mouthpiece. "The DPP supporters are refusing to leave the polling stations. They are shouting 'Invalid Election.'"

You take the phone. You switch into your "Governor" persona—calm, authoritative, the man who solved problems while others talked. "Tell the Director that order will be maintained," you say firmly. "Tell him that democracy is messy, but the numbers are final. I am the President. I will form a 'Grand Coalition' government. I will invite DPP members into the cabinet."

It is a lie, or at least, a desperate hope. You know A-Bian will never join you. He will besiege you.

You think of Lee Teng-hui in the Presidential Palace. The old man must be laughing his bitter laugh. He failed to install Lien, yes. But he has left you a poisoned chalice. He has left you a country divided down the middle, a legislature controlled by enemies, and a legitimacy crisis that will dog you from Day One. He broke the KMT to stop you, and though he failed to stop you, he succeeded in breaking the country.

Liu Sung-pan, the former Legislative Speaker who defected to your side, approaches with a glass of whiskey. "We beat the Black Gold," he grunts. "We beat the machine."

"We are the machine now," you correct him. "And it's broken."

You have to go out there. You have to face the cameras. You have to face the people. Not just your supporters—the fervent, orange-clad loyalists who worship you—but the millions of Taiwanese who just voted for Chen Shui-bian and are currently weeping in the rain.

You step onto the balcony. The cool night air hits you. The roar of the crowd is deafening, a wave of orange flags waving frantically. They don't care about the percentage. They only see the victory.

"My fellow countrymen!" you shout. The microphone feedback squeals.

"Tonight, the people have spoken! It was a close race! It was a hard fight!"

You look out at the dark skyline of Taipei. You can see the lights of the DPP headquarters in the distance. It is dark there, but you know they are not sleeping. They are sharpening their knives.

"I will be a President for all Taiwanese!" you declare, trying to sound convinced. "Whether you voted for Mr. Chen, or Mr. Lien, I am your servant! We must heal the wounds! We must look forward!"

The crowd cheers, but you feel the chill. You have won the title, but you have not won the heart of the island. You are a minority President, squeezed between a vengeful KMT establishment and a rising, furious DPP.

Chen Wan-shui squeezes your hand. You squeeze back, holding on for dear life.

The era of Soong has begun, but it begins not with a sunrise, but with a storm warning.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/soong24.jpg?v=1765967618250"})]); } if(!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 69 && quickstats[1] < 35 && aa[1].candidate === 67) { // --- English Content (High School Civics Class Simulation - Corrected History) --- const ENDING_HTML = `

【2023 High School Civics Class】The Script of the Comeback: Chen Shui-bian's "Political Rollercoaster"

Mr. Lin (Civics)

"Students, today we'll look back at a politician who won the mayoralty in 1994, lost the presidency in 2000, and then won the presidency in 2004. This experience of dramatic wins and losses forged Chen Shui-bian's political legend. Let's analyze how this 'undying cockroach' pulled off this miracle amidst James Soong's chaotic administration."

Xiao An (12th Grade)

"Mr. Lin, Ah-Bian won the Taipei Mayoralty in '94 but lost to Ma Ying-jeou in '98. Then in the 2000 Presidential Election, although his vote share wasn't the highest, he was only slightly behind Soong Chu-yu, ultimately losing as the second-place candidate. Having lost the '98 mayoralty and the 2000 presidency consecutively, it truly feels like a rollercoaster ride."

Mr. Lin (Civics)

"Exactly. This was the consequence of James Soong's narrow victory with the lowest vote share in history (less than 35%). Even though he won, in political science, this is called a legitimacy crisis. Only one-third of the people supported you! Chen Shui-bian seized on this, constantly questioning the legitimacy of President Soong. The four years from 2000 to 2004 became the most boisterous and chaotic period in Taiwan's history."

A-Ming (12th Grade)

"So what was it like those four years? Was it a street party every day?"

Mr. Lin (Civics)

"You could see it that way! The DPP turned those four years into a nationwide street movement carnival. Although Chen Shui-bian lost the election, he acted more like a president than Soong. He led crowds in the streets, demanding 'power back to the people' and challenging Soong's every policy. As for Soong? Lacking a popular mandate and facing legislative boycotts from hostile forces, his administrative capability was completely stalled. The nation saw no major construction, no reform, only endless political infighting and media smear campaigns. Society was utterly exhausted."

Xiao Hua (12th Grade)

"I see! The extreme of chaos is opportunity. The people were sick of the political deadlock during the Soong era and needed a strong figure to end the turmoil. Chen Shui-bian's accumulated popularity and mobilization power on the streets made him look like the only person who could clean up the mess."

Mr. Lin (Civics)

"It was this exhaustion that became the DPP's greatest asset. In the 2004 election, Chen Shui-bian barely had to campaign; the voters' subconscious thought was: four more years of Soong Chu-yu, and we might go crazy. Thus, Chen Shui-bian easily harvested the fatigue with the chaos, defeated Soong, successfully won the presidency, and was re-elected in 2012, ushering in eight years of DPP prominence. Soong Chu-yu faded from the political scene forever."

Chen Shui-bian's Political Cycle: From Low Point to Peak

1994: Elected Taipei Mayor

1998: Lost Taipei Mayoralty

2000-2004: Under Soong's term, Chen went from loser to Street Commander-in-Chief

2004-2012: Presidential Term (Re-elected)

2016-2020: Yu Shyi-kun (DPP)

2020-Present: Eric Chu (KMT)

Mr. Lin (Civics)

"So you see, a politician isn't finished just because they lose. Soong Chu-yu's four years of extreme instability actually served as the perfect springboard for Chen Shui-bian's comeback. This history teaches us that political victory and defeat often depend on accurately capturing the public's mood. And now, we are about to see if President Eric Chu can win his re-election bid in 2024."

The Sinner of History

"They burned the house down to kill a single mouse. And now, they stand in the ashes, wondering why the wolves are at the door."

The office of the "New Taiwanese Service Team" on Ren'ai Road is not silent. Silence would be a mercy. Instead, it is filled with the sounds of a massacre—not of bodies, but of dreams. You hear the sobbing of grown men, the shattering of glass against walls, and the incoherent screaming of staff members who cannot comprehend the numbers flashing on the television screens.

You, James Soong (Soong Chu-yu), sit in your leather chair, your body frozen in a state of shock that transcends grief. It is a physical paralysis. You stare at the breakdown:

1. Chen Shui-bian (DPP) - ELECTED.
2. Lien Chan (KMT).
3. James Soong (Independent).

Third.

The word tastes like poison in your mouth. You, the "Governor of the Province," the most popular politician in Taiwan for the last decade, the man who visited 309 townships, the man who personally paved the roads and built the bridges... you have been relegated to the dustbin of history. You are not even the runner-up. You are the spoiler. The loser.

A wave of nausea hits you, followed immediately by a white-hot, blinding rage. It wasn't the voters. The voters loved you. You saw it in their eyes in Taichung, in Kaohsiung, in the Hakka villages. They wanted to vote for you.

It was Them. The Establishment.

You close your eyes and you see his face. Ma Ying-jeou. The KMT's "Golden Boy," the Mayor of Taipei. You recall the press conference from just a few days ago. Ma, with his clean, honest face, looking into the camera and holding up those "internal polls."

"Lien Chan has surged," Ma had lied, his voice trembling with faux sincerity. "Soong Chu-yu is out of the race. The gap is widening. If you want to stop A-Bian, you must vote for Lien."

It was a lie. A calculated, cold-blooded fabrication designed to trigger the "Dump-Save" (棄保) effect. And it worked. God help you, it worked. The wavering voters, terrified of a Chen Shui-bian presidency and the war it might bring, panicked. They looked at Ma Ying-jeou—the symbol of integrity—and they believed him. They abandoned you to "save" the Republic, and in doing so, they handed the Republic to the separatists.

Chen Wan-shui is kneeling beside your chair. She is weeping, not for herself, but for you. She holds your hand, her tears wetting your knuckles. "They are wicked, Chu-yu," she sobs. "They are wicked people. Lee Teng-hui... he would rather see the country die than see you win."

The name acts like a galvanic shock. Lee Teng-hui. The "Godfather" in the Presidential Palace. The architect of this tragedy. He knew Lien Chan couldn't win. Lien has the charisma of a damp rag. Lee knew it. But Lee hated you. He feared you. You were the only one who could unite the Mainlanders and the Taiwanese, the only one who could actually govern this island effectively. And that made you dangerous.

So he invented the "Chung Hsing Bills" (Xing Piao) scandal. He dragged your name through the mud, painting you—the cleanest administrator in government—as a thief. He used the courts, the prosecutors, and the state media to bleed you dry for months. And when that wasn't enough, he ordered Ma Ying-jeou to execute the final betrayal with the fake polls.

And what is the result? You look at the TV screen. Chen Shui-bian is on stage, wearing his green cap, raising his hands in victory. The "Green Terror" has arrived. The KMT has lost power for the first time in 55 years. The Republic of China is now in the hands of a party that has "Independence" in its charter.

Chang Chao-hsiung, your running mate, slams his fist onto the table, shattering a tea cup. "They are the sinners of history!" Chang screams, his usual doctor's demeanor gone. "The KMT leadership... Lee, Lien, Ma... they are the sinners of history! They split the Blue vote! Together we had 60%! Divided, we gave it to A-Bian!"

He is right. If you add your votes to Lien's, you would have crushed Chen Shui-bian. It would have been a landslide. But the KMT chose suicide over compromise.

You stand up. Your legs feel heavy, like lead. You walk to the window. Outside, the rain is pouring down on Taipei, washing away the orange flags that litter the gutter. You see your supporters huddled in the street. They are not leaving. They are hugging each other, crying openly. They know what happened. They know they were cheated.

A young aide approaches you, terrified. "Governor... the press is waiting. You have to concede."

"Concede?" you snarl, turning on him. "Concede to whom? To the man who won with few votes? Or to the party that lied its way to second place?"

But you know you must go out there. You are James Soong. You must have dignity, even when your enemies have none.

You straighten your tie. You wipe the sweat from your forehead. You think of the millions of people who voted for you—the "New Taiwanese." They were the ones who wanted to transcend the ethnic hatred, who wanted a government that worked. And tonight, they have been told that their voice doesn't matter because the system is rigged against outsiders.

You step out onto the balcony. The crowd sees you and a sound rises up—a low, mournful wail that turns into a roar of defiance. "Song Chu-yu! Song Chu-yu!"

You grip the podium. Your knuckles are white. You look into the cameras, imagining Lee Teng-hui watching from his office, imagining Ma Ying-jeou watching from City Hall.

"My friends," you say, your voice shaking with suppressed fury. "We fought the good fight."

"We fought against the money! We fought against the lies! We fought against the entire state machine!"

The crowd screams in agreement. "Invalid Election! Invalid Election!" they chant.

"Tonight, the KMT has lost the country," you declare, pointing a finger at the invisible enemy. "Not because the people wanted change, but because the leadership of the KMT betrayed the people! They used false numbers! They used character assassination! And in doing so, they have become the Sinners of the Ages (千古罪人)!"

You pause, breathing heavily. You look at Chen Wan-shui standing in the wings, wiping her eyes. You realize that your political career in the KMT is over. You can never go back. They burned the bridge, and then they blew up the cliff.

"But we are not finished!" you shout, trying to find a ember of hope in the ashes. "We will form a new path! We will be the true voice of the people! We will not let this country fall into ruin!"

But deep down, as you look at the victorious images of Chen Shui-bian on the giant screens across the street, you know the truth. The dam has broken. The genie is out of the bottle. The "Third Place" is a graveyard.

You turn away from the crowd, feeling older than you have ever felt in your life. You were the Crown Prince. You were the Governor. You were the inevitable President. And tonight, thanks to the envy of an old man and the lies of a young one, you are nothing but a footnote in the tragedy of the Republic.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/zhehyz.jpg?v=1765967833114"})]); } if(!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 67 && aa[1].candidate === 68) { // --- English Content (Soong's Reflection and Historical Fate - Expanded Thoughts) --- const ENDING_HTML = `

【2024 Political Hermit】James Soong: The Third-Party's Destiny

California, USA, a sunny Tuesday afternoon. Familiar Taiwanese Mandarin drifts from the television.

James Soong gently put down his newspaper, his eyes fixed on the screen. The anchor was analyzing the "three-way race" for the 2024 Taiwanese presidential election: the DPP’s Lai Ching-te, the KMT’s Eric Chu, and the TPP’s Ko Wen-je. He had been in the United States for nearly a quarter of a century, living the quiet life of a political hermit, far from the humidity and clamor of Taipei’s politics.

The 2000 election, to him, was not a competition but a sacrifice. The KMT's "Abandon Soong to Save Lien" strategy, though deployed too late and with insufficient force, ultimately worked. Votes flowed to Lien Chan, securing him second place and dropping Soong to third. This failure allowed Chen Shui-bian to achieve the improbable victory, ending the KMT's fifty years of rule.

He knew he couldn't stay in Taiwan after the defeat. He was branded by the Pan-Blue camp as the chief sinner who handed power to the DPP. The public and the party machine didn't need to analyze right or wrong; they just needed an outlet for their anger. For the KMT's survival—and Lien Chan's future—he had to be the one sacrificed and forgotten. So, just days after the loss, he quietly flew to the US under the guise of "recuperation," completely wiping his political slate clean.

Historical Trajectory: Stability Bought by His Exile

Soong's exile unexpectedly accelerated the Pan-Blue camp's healing. Without his continuous obstruction, Lien Chan successfully consolidated all Pan-Blue votes in 2004, easily defeated Chen Shui-bian, and governed stably until 2012.

In 2012, the KMT passed the baton to the clean-imaged Ma Ying-jeou, who easily defeated the DPP’s Tsai Ing-wen, extending the KMT's rule until 2020.

For two decades, Soong Chu-yu's figure never reappeared on Taiwan's political stage. The PFP he founded was already defunct in all but name, its members mostly retired or quietly returned to the embrace of the KMT. The former Governor, once supported by millions, ultimately facilitated sixteen years of stable KMT rule—while he himself was permanently excluded from the center of power.

2024: Ko Wen-je's Reflection

His gaze settled on Ko Wen-je, the TPP chairman in a white jacket, attempting to be the third force to break the KMT-DPP deadlock.

"Alas..." Soong murmured, his sigh deeper. He saw Ko's naive idealism, and he also saw the formidable, underlying power structure of the two major parties, capable of consuming everything. He knew that when the life-and-death moment of voting arrived, the KMT would ruthlessly reintroduce the narrative of "division is the original sin," forcing voters to fall back into line.

He slowly rose and turned off the television. Twenty-four years of exile had taught him: in the Taiwanese political landscape, sometimes the greatest tragedy is not defeat, but causing the split. And Ko Wen-je was walking the exact same road he had walked—the road to political oblivion. He lamented for Ko, and he lamented for himself.

`; e.pages.push(ENDING_HTML); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/obx1JX0.jpeg'})]); // Setting music: Soft music with a sense of lament and memory if (songChange != 1) { songChange = 1 const lienWin = new Playlist(); const lienWinSong50 = new Song( "草螟弄雞公 (Live)", "Luo Da-you", "https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/hOHA6G6lUzoqii0jLnYgFnMSjJ8yUPsX8C7tS47sAKYiFt39siD_nXUXrTBBeZR6ilLe9pmR6-dBrFoU9A", "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/%E8%8D%89%E8%9E%9F%E5%BC%84%E9%9B%9E%E5%85%AC%20(Live)%20-%20Lo%20Ta-yu%20(youtube).mp3?v=1764106752327" ); lienWin.addSong(lienWinSong50,0); changePlaylist(lienWin); } } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 67 && aa[1].candidate === 68) { // HTML Content: Historical table based on the new timeline (Scenario 15 - DPP -> KMT -> KMT -> KMT). Ending I: Soong Wave, Orange-Green Confrontation // Condition: Chen Shui-bian wins and Soong Chu-yu's PV > 40% (Chen wins by a narrow margin) if(!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 67 && quickstats[1] > 40 && aa[1].candidate === 69) { e.pages.push(`

The Uncrowned King of a Broken Land

"We united the people, but we could not defeat the ghost. The majority has spoken, but the minority has taken the throne."

The roar from the street below is not the sound of a celebration, nor is it the sound of a defeat. It is the sound of an insurrection. The air inside the "New Taiwanese Service Team" headquarters on Ren'ai Road is vibrating, physically shaking from the collective rage of half the population of Taiwan. It is a dangerous, volatile noise—the sound of millions of people who realized they did everything right, and were still robbed by the cruel arithmetic of democracy.

You, James Soong, stand before the wall of monitors, your hands gripping the back of a chair so hard the leather is tearing. You stare at the numbers. They are grotesque. They are impossible.

You focus on your own tally: ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%.

You have lost. You have lost by a margin so thin it is almost invisible. You have secured a vote share that, in any other election in the history of the Republic, would guarantee a landslide victory. You have done what the pundits said was impossible: you successfully triggered the "Strategic Voting" (棄保). The voters listened to you. They abandoned the KMT. They dumped Lien Chan into the dustbin of history, reducing the century-old party to a humiliating, single-digit rump. They consolidated behind you to save the Republic of China.

But it wasn't enough. Chen Shui-bian has edged ahead. Just barely. A ghost of a lead.

Chen Wan-shui is standing in the corner, her face pale, pressing a handkerchief to her lips. She looks terrified. Not of the loss, but of what comes next. "The people are furious, Chu-yu," she whispers, her voice barely audible over the chanting outside. "They aren't going home. They are marching on the Presidential Palace. They are saying the election is invalid. They are saying A-Bian stole it."

You look at the television screens. She is right. The streets of Taipei are a sea of orange and blue flags, now merged into a single river of fury. Police barricades are being overrun. Molotov cocktails are being thrown at the KMT headquarters—not by DPP supporters, but by your supporters, furious at the KMT for not withdrawing Lien Chan. If Lien had just dropped out... if he had just taken his pitiful remaining votes and endorsed you... you would be President with a massive absolute majority. The country would be united.

Instead, Lien Chan—the stubborn, wooden puppet of the establishment—stayed in the race just long enough to act as the spoiler. He didn't win; he committed suicide, and he took the Republic of China down with him. And behind him, you see the shadow of Lee Teng-hui. The old man must be sitting in his office, watching the city burn. Did he plan this? Did he know that even if the "Dump-Lien" effect happened, it wouldn't be clean enough? He has handed the country to the separatists rather than let you, the "Mainlander," take power.

Chang Chao-hsiung, your running mate, is red-faced, shouting into a telephone. "No! We do not concede! How can we concede?" He slams the phone down and turns to you, his eyes wild. "Governor, look at your numbers! ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%! And we lose? The invalid ballots... there are 300,000 invalid ballots! This is fraud! This is a coup by the establishment and the DPP combined!"

You walk to the window. The rain is lashing down, but it cannot extinguish the fires burning in the streets. You see the faces of your supporters—veterans, farmers, middle-class mothers. They are screaming. They feel the injustice in their bones. They constitute the largest bloc of this island, yet they are shut out of power.

This is not just a defeat; it is a constitutional crisis. A President elected with a minority of the vote, while the vast majority of the people voted for a pro-ROC platform (splitting their votes between you and Lien), will have no legitimacy. The legislature will be hostile. The military will be suspicious. The streets will be ungovernable.

A senior general calls your private line. You stare at the ringing phone. You know what he wants to say. The military is restless. They are waiting for a signal. If you go out onto that balcony and declare the election invalid, if you call for a "Restore the Republic" movement, you could bring the government to its knees. You could stop A-Bian before he even takes the oath.

But you look at Wan-shui. You see the fear in her eyes. You remember the martial law era. You remember the chaos of the transition. Do you want to be the man who starts a civil war?

"Chu-yu," Wan-shui says softly, touching your arm. "You are the un-crowned King. Don't become the Warlord."

You pick up the phone. "Stand down," you tell the general, your voice sounding like gravel. "The Republic of China is a democracy. We will fight this in the courts, not in the barracks."

You hang up. The decision is made. But the bitterness tastes like bile.

You step out onto the balcony to face the mob. The noise is physical. It hits you like a shockwave. "Song Zongtong! Song Zongtong!" They refuse to accept the result. They are waving signs that read "The Nation is Dead" and "Lien Chan is a Sinner."

You grip the podium. You are the tragic hero of this opera. You won the argument. You won the campaign. You destroyed the KMT. You mobilized the people. But you lost the count.

"My friends!" you bellow, and for a moment, the riot quiets down to listen to its leader.

"We have won the hearts of the Taiwanese people!" you shout, pointing at the sky. "The numbers on that screen are cold, but your blood is hot! We have proven that the KMT is dead! We have proven that the people wanted a Third Way!"

You pause, letting the rain soak your shirt. "They may take the office," you snarl, pointing toward the Presidential Palace, "but they will never take our dignity! We are the moral majority! We are the guardians of the Republic! And we will be watching them!"

The crowd roars, a sound of defiance and grief. But as you look out over the chaotic, fractured city, you know the truth. The "Golden Decade" is over. A-Bian will take power, but he will rule over a ruin. The KMT is shattered. The PFP is angry. The country is split down the middle, held together only by the fragile tape of a democratic system that just failed its stress test.

You turn away from the microphone, feeling the immense weight of the "What Ifs." If only Lien had stepped down. If only the missiles hadn't fired. If only you had shaken one more hand. You secured ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}% of the vote, a historic achievement, yet tonight, you are a king without a crown, watching your kingdom burn.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/soong40.png?v=1765970443468"})]); } if(!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 67 && quickstats[1] > 40 && aa[1].candidate === 69) { // --- English Content (President Soong's Perspective and Succession Planning) --- const ENDING_HTML = `

The President's Succession Dilemma: The Heir to the Soong Dynasty

Presidential Office Reception Room, March 2011. PFP President James Soong holds a closed-door meeting with Chief Aide Vivian Huang (Huang Shan-shan).

In the office, President Soong pushes a list containing the names of three potential successors toward Huang Shan-shan. This list carries the future of the People First Party (Orange Camp) and will determine whether Taiwan's politics can maintain the long-term state of Orange-Green Confrontation.

Soong recalls the 2000 election: he lost bitterly despite an astonishing vote share exceeding 40%. Yet, this result utterly defeated the KMT's Lien Chan, pushing him to third place and ensuring the KMT's brand was effectively dead. Subsequently, by securing numerous seats in the 2001 legislative election, the PFP firmly established its leadership over the opposition, setting the political landscape as an Orange vs. Green showdown. This momentum allowed him to defeat Chen Shui-bian in 2004 and successfully fend off Hsieh Chang-ting's challenge in 2008. Now, his eight-year term is nearing its end, and the moment for transition has arrived. He must ensure the orange torch continues to burn brightly.

President Soong:

“Shan-shan, time is running out. The DPP will certainly launch an all-out counterattack this time. Su Tseng-chang, Annette Lu, Yu Shyi-kun, and Frank Hsieh—any of them could emerge as the challenger. We must select someone who can both safeguard the Orange Camp's eight years of achievements and win in 2012.”

Vivian Huang:

“Mr. President, the DPP’s challenges are multifaceted. Su Tseng-chang’s administrative efficiency will encroach on our strength; Annette Lu's ideology will mobilize the deep-green base. In this battle, we need candidates with the ability to reassure the public and transcend the Pan-Blue/Pan-Green divide.”

Successor Analysis: Conservatism, Tradition, or High-Stakes Gamble?

A. Vice President Chang Chao-hsiung: Conservatism and Professionalism

President Soong:

“Vice President Chang is professional and can continue my 'efficient governance' style. But you see, he lacks charisma for the streets. If he faces Su Tseng-chang, won't the campaign momentum be too subdued?”

Vivian Huang:

“That's the risk. He is suitable as a steady successor, but his 'shield' might be too thin against the DPP's heavy firepower. We need a more aggressive candidate who can take the offensive.”

B. Premier Wu Den-yih: Tradition and Grassroots

President Soong:

“Wu Den-yih has deep grassroots experience and is an eloquent speaker—an ideal choice for securing traditional votes in central and southern Taiwan. But he was, after all, a KMT heavyweight. Will the Orange Camp voters have reservations about 'returning to the old era'? I worry about losing the youth vote.”

Vivian Huang:

“He certainly can win over some traditional supporters, but he also gives the DPP an excuse to attack us, dragging us back into the KMT's past scandals. His strengths and weaknesses are equally obvious, making it difficult to achieve a high-vote breakthrough.”

C. Business Magnate Terry Gou (Guo Tai-ming): Change and the High-Stakes Gamble

Vivian Huang:

“Mr. President, Mr. Gou is our 'nuclear-level' option. He completely breaks free from the Blue-Green framework, appealing to the economy and technology. He will be hugely attractive to young voters and centrists. This is the ultimate change card.”

President Soong:

“But the risk is too high. He has zero political experience, and his judgment on cross-strait and international affairs is untested. If he missteps in a debate, or displays the 'assertiveness' of a businessman rather than the 'gravitas' of a president, our efforts could all be in vain.”

President Soong:

“The conservative choice has the least risk, but limited potential; the traditional choice is stable but difficult to expand; the high-stakes gamble has the highest potential, but extreme risk.”

Vivian Huang:

“Mr. President, the lesson we learned from the 2000 defeat is that: only by bravely pursuing change can we make voters forget the pain of failure. If we only nominate a 'conservative,' it will be difficult to generate enough enthusiasm to counter the DPP’s 2012 resurgence.”

Soong slowly walked to the window, watching the traffic flow below in Taipei. He knew Huang was right. The PFP's rise itself was a daring gamble. The 2012 election will be the pivotal battle for Taiwan's Post-Soong Era, allowing for no conservatism. The scale in his heart was already tipping toward the person who carried the greatest risk, but who could best break the political stalemate.

The Tragedy of the Century

"We paved every road. We built every bridge. We touched every hand. And in the end, we were defeated not by the enemy, but by a lie told by our own brothers."

The rain in Taipei tonight is relentless. It does not cleanse; it drowns. It falls upon the orange flags scattered in the gutters of Ren'ai Road, turning the paper slogans promising "A New Future" into gray, dissolving pulp. Inside the headquarters of the New Taiwanese Service Team, the air is thick with a suffocating mixture of cigarette smoke, sweat, and the metallic taste of absolute, crushing disbelief. You, James Soong, stand at the window of your private office, looking out at the blur of streetlights. You are the "Governor." The "Commander." The man who visited 309 townships. The man who speaks Hakka to the Hakkas, Minnan to the Islanders, and Mandarin to the Soldiers. You are the most capable administrator this island has ever produced. And you have lost.

The numbers on the television screen burn with a cold, green malevolence. They are etched into your soul forever. You focus only on your own number: ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%. It is a massive number. It is a number that represents millions of screaming voices, millions of hopes, and a political movement built from nothing but sheer will. In any normal election, in any two-way race, this number would guarantee a landslide victory. But this was not a normal election. This was a suicide pact.

You turn away from the window. The silence in the room is heavy. Chang Chao-hsiung, your running mate, is sitting with his head in his hands. He is a doctor, a man of science, but there is no medicine for this. "We beat the KMT," Chang whispers, his voice trembling. "We destroyed the establishment candidate. We took the Center. We took the North. How did we lose?" But you know exactly how you lost. It wasn't because of Chen Shui-bian. A-Bian played his role perfectly, mobilizing the discontent, the "Formosa" dreamers. He was a worthy opponent. No, you did not lose to the DPP. You were murdered by your own family.

You close your eyes and you see the face of Ma Ying-jeou. The "Golden Boy." The Mayor of Taipei. The man who stood before the cameras just days ago, his face a mask of earnest, clean-cut integrity, and told the biggest lie in the history of Taiwanese politics. "Our internal polls show the KMT candidate is surging," Ma had said, holding up those fabricated charts. "Soong Chu-yu is out of the race. If you vote for Soong, you are letting A-Bian win." The "Fake Polls" (假民調). It was a dagger in the dark. It stopped your momentum dead. It terrified the wavering voters—the elderly veterans, the nervous middle class who feared war above all else. They wanted to vote for you, but Ma scared them back to the KMT candidate. And those votes—those precious, stolen votes that went to a hopeless third-place finisher—were the votes that should have carried you to the Presidency.

And behind Ma, looming like a dark shadow over the Presidential Palace, is Lee Teng-hui. The "Godfather." The man who treated you like a son when you were his enforcer, and then tried to destroy you when you became too popular. The "Chung Hsing Bills" (Xing Piao) scandal. The months of investigation. The character assassination. Lee didn't care if the KMT lost. He didn't care if the Republic of China fell into the hands of the independence movement. He only cared about one thing: Killing James Soong. Tonight, Lee Teng-hui has his wish. He has destroyed the KMT to stop you. He has handed the keys of the nation to Chen Shui-bian, a man he secretly admires, rather than let the "Mainlander" governor take the throne. It is a Greek tragedy of spite. The teacher has burned down the school to prevent the student from becoming the principal.

A soft hand touches your arm. It is Chen Wan-shui. Your wife. "Sister Wan-shui" to the millions who adore her. She looks older tonight. The campaign has taken a terrible toll on her health. The insults, the lawsuits, the sleepless nights. She gazes at you with eyes that are filled not with disappointment, but with a profound, aching sadness for the country. "They didn't deserve you, Chu-yu," she says softly. "You worked harder than anyone. You loved them more than anyone. But fear... fear is stronger than love." You look at her and your heart breaks. You remember the rallies. The old women in the markets grabbing your hands, their calloused palms pressing against yours, crying, "Governor Soong, save us." You remember the aboriginal chiefs wrapping you in their traditional cloth. You remember the soldiers saluting you. You were the "New Taiwanese." You were the bridge. And now, the bridge is broken. The country is split into three jagged pieces. Green, Blue, and Orange. And the Green minority has seized the crown because the Blue and Orange could not reconcile.

The door bursts open. A senior aide runs in, his face flushed, holding a portable radio. "Governor, you have to hear this. The KMT headquarters... it's a war zone." You turn on the news. The scene is apocalyptic. Thousands of furious supporters—many of them KMT members who voted for you, or loyalists who realized too late they were tricked—are surrounding the KMT central office. They are throwing eggs, stones, and paint. They are scaling the barricades. The chant is deafening: "Lee Teng-hui, Step Down! Lee Teng-hui, Traitor!" They are beating up KMT officials. They are demanding justice. They know, deep in their bones, that this election was a fraud—not of the ballot count, but of the truth. They know that if the KMT candidate had withdrawn, or if the fake polls hadn't been released, you would be winning with a massive absolute majority.

Your phone rings. It is a general from the military police. "Mr. Soong," he says, his voice tight. "The situation is critical. The crowd is out of control. If you give the word... if you lead them... we don't know what will happen." The temptation is a physical weight in your chest. You could do it. You could walk out there, drive to the KMT headquarters, and stand on top of a car. You could declare the election invalid due to the Xing Piao manipulation. You could call for a recount, a new election. You have millions of votes—far more than the KMT candidate. You have the moral mandate. You could start a revolution tonight. But then you look at Wan-shui. You look at the rain falling on the peaceful, democratic island you helped build during the transition from martial law. You remember your mentor, Chiang Ching-kuo. He lifted the ban on parties so that this day could happen. Even if it is a bitter day. "No," you say into the phone. "We follow the law. We are not warlords. We are the servants of the people."

You hang up the phone. You adjust your orange tie. The color of the earth. The color of the harvest. It is time to face the music. You walk out to the main hall. The staff are weeping openly. Grown men are hugging each other, sobbing. They feel the injustice like a knife in the gut. You step onto the balcony. The lights blind you. The roar of the crowd is a mixture of adoration and agony. "Song Zongtong! Song Zongtong!" They refuse to accept the result. "My friends!" you shout, your voice cracking slightly before finding its old iron strength. "The rain falls on the just and the unjust alike!" The crowd quiets, listening to their leader.

"We have fought the greatest campaign in the history of Taiwan!" you declare. "We had no party assets! We had no government machine! We had only the people! And look at what we did!" You point to the screen showing your vote count: ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%. "We have defeated the century-old Kuomintang!" you shout, and the crowd roars with a savage joy. "We have proven that the people are the masters, not the parties!" You pause. "Mr. Chen has won the count," you say, and the boos are deafening. You raise a hand. "But we... we have won the heart of Taiwan. We are the guardians of the Republic of China. We will not disappear. We will form a new force. A force that puts the People First!"

As the confetti cannons fire—a planned celebration for a victory that didn't happen—the orange paper mixes with the rain, falling like autumn leaves. You look toward the distance, toward the dark outline of the Presidential Palace. A-Bian will move in there soon. He will find it a lonely place. He has won the presidency, but he has not won the country. The majority—the combined Pan-Blue majority—is against him. And you? You are the tragic hero. The man who was too capable for his boss, too popular for his party, and too honest for the dirty tricks of his rivals. You have fallen just short of the summit. Chiou I-jen and the DPP are celebrating a miracle. Lee Teng-hui is smiling in the shadows. But as you look at the tear-streaked faces of your supporters, you make a silent vow. You will not fade away. You will build the People First Party. You will hold the balance of power. You will be the Kingmaker, if not the King. But tonight... tonight, you simply have to endure the pain of being the greatest President Taiwan never had.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/2abe92c7bca085d0f4566cea15348132.jpg?v=1765970887938"})]); } if(!exclusive_action_executed &&aa[0].candidate === 67 && quickstats[1] >= 35 && quickstats[1] <= 40 && aa[1].candidate === 69) { const ENDING_HTML = `

The Twenty-Year Historical Rite: Fated Destiny and the Eternal 2000

Time: Late 2019, Presidential Election Debate. Setting: Under the Spotlight. Candidates: Tsai Ing-wen (Green), Han Kuo-yu (Blue), James Soong (Orange).

Standing at the center of the debate stage, James Soong felt he was no longer a candidate, but an embodiment of history. The air around him condensed into an invisible wall, separating him from the restless crowd below. This was his fifth time standing in this "Roman Colosseum," each appearance an iterative ritual commemorating the defeat two decades prior. He remembered clearly how, in 2000, he lost with a stunningly high vote count, trailing Chen Shui-bian by only a tiny margin, yet irrevocably severing the umbilical cord of the old system. That fracture, like the flap of a butterfly's wing, gently redirected the river of Taiwanese politics onto a completely different course.

The Clamor of Blue and Green: The Two Poles of Destiny

Now, he was compelled to listen to the two leaders of the mainstream forces before him; their sharp dialogue was a sarcastic summary of twenty years of political disorder.

Tsai Ing-wen (Calm yet pointed): "I just heard Mayor Han state unequivocally that he does not accept 'One Country, Two Systems.' But when Xi Jinping first began to speak of the '1992 Consensus, One Country, Two Systems,' Mayor Han's reply was that he wasn't clear, he equivocated, and even went to visit the Liaison Office in March, creating an atmosphere conducive to 'One Country, Two Systems.' I must tell Mayor Han: perhaps you reject 'One Country, Two Systems' now, but a leader should not only adopt a position when forced by social pressure. A leader must lead society, making swift decisions when they must be made, and guiding the people's reaction to any changes in the situation, not merely reacting after the public has reacted or pressure has mounted."
Han Kuo-yu (Passionate and retaliatory): "I absolutely respect media freedom, but the Taiwan 2020 Presidential election has never been this dirty in the past year and a half. For a year and a half, what if 90% of the media were attacking Chairman Soong, and even your beloved Sister Wan-Shui, with 100% of the internet blackening your name—accusing you of drinking and embracing women, attacking your father-in-law, calling you a gangster, a rogue, claiming your children weren't yours, attacking all of your father-in-law's real estate, and attacking whether Sister Wan-Shui interfered in politics during your time as Taiwan Provincial Governor? If you were attacked continuously for a year and a half, would you speak like this today? Seeing me attacked and beaten, you call for me to be poised and respect the media. Chairman Soong, it seems easy to watch others take a beating. Has Taiwan's decades of democratic politics ever been this dirty, this vile, in the 2020 election? Vice Presidential candidate Lai Ching-te, from the DPP, is sitting right here—bear witness! What were you called by the online army in April and May of this year? Weren't you begging for mercy?"
James Soong (Deep and lamenting): "Mayor Han, since childhood, my father told me, and my grandmother taught him, that the Gods are watching three feet above your head. I govern with this belief: politics is a business of conscience. Politics must truly care for the suffering of the people. It is good to practice virtue in public service. Frankly speaking, man acts, Heaven watches. In fact, step by step, the people will not forget the efforts you have made. Travel anywhere in Taiwan, and everyone knows that those road signs were initiated by James Soong; if you have an urgent need for the toilet on the highway, the initiative to start building restrooms at all gas stations was also begun by James Soong. The small matters of the people are the great matters of the government; the government must not treat them lightly."

The Solitude of the Rational Observer and the Adherence to Chinese Identity

Soong knew that his words were merely insignificant noise to the ears of the fervent Blue and Green voters. His voice represented the rejected path of rational centrism.

When the camera focused on him, he let out a final, desperate cry: “Fellow citizens, my loyalty to the Republic of China is beyond doubt! My Chinese identity is built upon an appreciation for the culture, history, and shared heritage. This sentiment has never conflicted with my deep love for Taiwan. I urge everyone: stop being held hostage by the ideologies of the Blue and Green camps, and step out of this swamp of fate!”

He tried to reach out, as if to grasp the audience's attention, but the spotlights were too bright; all he saw were blurry figures. A deep sorrow washed over him: for twenty years, he had been here, running relentlessly like Sisyphus pushing his boulder, simply to prove that the mandate that fell short in 2000 was not extinguished.

The Echo of History: An Eternal Commemoration

He slowly returned to his seat and closed his eyes. Only the voices of Tsai and Han remained, merging into a continuous drone. He no longer viewed this as an election, but as an eternal commemoration of his own political life.

Ma Ying-jeou's victories (2008, 2012) proved the consolidation of the Pan-Blue forces, while Tsai Ing-wen's success (2016, seeking re-election in 2020) established the dominance of local identity. Soong's existence became the beginning and the footnote to all of it. Had he won in 2000, perhaps Taiwan would not have experienced such drastic party rotations, nor such distinctly divided Blue and Green walls.

But history was fixed. Beneath his feet lay the trajectory of twenty years of Taiwanese politics, filled with missed opportunities, regret, and endless bickering. He opened his eyes, wearing the calm composure of an old statesman who had seen it all, transcending victory and defeat. He would finish this fight, not for the win, but to prove: he was here, and he had offered a better choice.

The Broken Wave

"We aimed for the stars, but gravity is a cruel mistress. The system is broken, but it is still strong enough to keep us out."

The rain falling on Taipei is quiet tonight. It does not drum with the fury of a storm, nor does it wash away the sins of the city. It simply falls, steady and cold, soaking the few remaining orange flags that lie abandoned on the sidewalk of Ren'ai Road. Inside the headquarters of the "New Taiwanese Service Team," the mood is not one of outrage, but of a deep, exhausting melancholy. It is the atmosphere of a party that has gone on too long, where the music has stopped but the guests are too tired to leave.

You, James Soong, stand before the television monitors. You are the "Governor." The man who defied the establishment. The man who promised a Third Way. But the numbers on the screen do not lie, and they do not flatter. You have secured ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}% of the vote. It is a respectable number. It is enough to defeat the official Kuomintang candidate, Lien Chan, who languishes in third place. But it is not enough to challenge Chen Shui-bian. It is not even close.

In the silence of your private office, you face the hard truth: The "Soong Wave" hit a breakwater. You thought you could sweep the island. You thought the people were ready to abandon the old party loyalties entirely. But you underestimated the Machine. You underestimated the stickiness of the KMT's "Iron Votes," even when led by a weak candidate. And perhaps, you overestimated your own invincibility.

Chang Chao-hsiung, your running mate, sits on the sofa, removing his glasses to rub his tired eyes. "The Xing Piao (Chung Hsing Bills) scandal," he murmurs, staring at the floor. "It stuck, Governor. We tried to explain it. We tried to sue. But the mud stuck. The middle class... they stayed home. Or they went back to the KMT."

You nod slowly. Lee Teng-hui knew what he was doing. The old fox in the Presidential Palace didn't need to destroy you completely; he just needed to damage you enough to keep you under 35%. He painted you as corrupt, as a man of the "Old Era," and despite your 309 township visits, despite your sweat and tears, enough voters believed him. They looked at you and saw a defecting warlord rather than a savior.

Chen Wan-shui walks in, holding a cup of ginseng tea. She looks frail. The campaign has aged her. She places the tea on your desk and touches your hand. "You still beat the Party, Chu-yu," she says softly, trying to find a silver lining. "You ran as an independent and you beat the KMT. That has never happened before."

"But A-Bian won," you reply, your voice raspy. "And he won clearly."

This is the bitterest pill. If the vote had been closer, if you had reached 40%, you could claim a moral victory. You could claim that you were robbed by the split. But at ${quickstats[1].toFixed(1)}%, the narrative changes. You are not the "Uncrowned King." You are simply the spoiler. The history books will record that James Soong split the conservative vote, handed the presidency to the independence movement, and failed to build a majority coalition of his own.

You look at the map on the wall. It is not the sea of orange you dreamed of. You won the solid blue districts, yes. You took the Hakka belt. But the South is deep Green. And the North... the North is a fractured mess of Blue and Orange. You didn't unite the opposition; you merely divided it.

The phone rings. It is a call from a KMT elder, one of the few who still speaks to you. "The Chairman is resigning," the voice says. "Lee Teng-hui is out. The party is in ruins. We need to talk about... reunification."

You hang up. The vultures are already circling. They want you back. Not as a leader, but as a prodigal son returning to save the family estate. They want your votes, but they don't want you. They will blame you for the loss. They will say, "If Soong hadn't run, Lien would have won." They will ignore the fact that Lien was a disastrous candidate. They will pin the "Sinner of History" label on your chest and ask you to wear it with pride.

You step out into the main hall. The staff looks at you with a mixture of love and pity. There are no riots tonight. There is no anger at the gates. Just a profound sense of "what might have been." The energy of the rallies—the "fever" that gripped the island—has broken.

You walk onto the balcony. The crowd is smaller than you expected. The die-hards are there, waving their flags, but the casual voters have already gone home to watch the new President-elect on TV. You grip the podium. You have to be strong for them. You have to pretend that this is a beginning, not an end.

"My friends," you say, your voice echoing in the wet night air. "We have walked a lonely road."

"We stood up against the giants!" you shout, trying to inject fire into the cold ashes. "We proved that a man without a party can still shake the foundations of the Republic!"

The crowd cheers, but it is a polite cheer. They know. They know the revolution stalled.

"Mr. Chen has won," you acknowledge, and the boos are half-hearted. "But we are not going away. We will form a new party! A People First Party! We will be the watchdog in the legislature! We will ensure that the Republic of China is safe!"

But as you speak the words, you feel the hollowness of them. A "Third Party" in Taiwan's system is a difficult beast. Without the presidency, without the resources of the state, how long can you keep this movement together? How long before your supporters drift back to the KMT or accept the DPP reality?

You look toward the Presidential Palace. The lights are blazing. A-Bian is preparing his victory speech. He will speak of a "New Era." And you? You are the ghost of the era that just passed. You successfully killed the KMT's dominance, but you died in the effort.

Chen Wan-shui stands in the shadows, watching you. You realize that she is the only thing you have truly won in this election. The loyalty of the people is fleeting; the loyalty of family is absolute.

You finish your speech and wave to the crowd. You step back inside, away from the glare of the lights. The "Soong Wave" has receded, leaving you stranded on the beach, looking at a wreckage that is partly of your own making. You are the second most powerful man in Taiwan, in a system that only cares about the first.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/9da0340204c885d30ad240c0ec34d263.jpg?v=1765973961731"})]); } if(!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 67 && quickstats[1] < 35 && aa[1].candidate === 69) { // --- 中英雙語褒揚令 (藝術擴寫版 - 含更新榮典之璽) --- const ENDING_HTML = `

褒　揚　令

故 親民黨創黨人 宋楚瑜先生，資稟穎秀，智慮宏遠。早歲投身公職，允文允武，歷任新聞局長、行政院祕書長等中樞要職，擘劃國家形象，綜理擘劃，夙著政績。尤以出任臺灣省政府主席暨末任民選省長，躬親下縣，勤走基層，推動「新臺灣人」理念與基層建設，完成公路網、水源地、垃圾場等重大工程，政績彪炳，譽滿士林，深獲各界讚譽，贏得「超級省長」之美稱，奠定臺灣地方自治與現代化之深厚基石。

晚近雖迭經政治波折，毅然創建親民黨，矢志憲政，堅守中道理念。數度參選總統，雖未竟全功，然其對理想之執著，對國家命運之關切，卓然獨立，足為典範。綜其生平，以天下為己任，勤奮不懈，忠勤不二，其對民主憲政發展之貢獻，厥功至偉。遽聞溘逝，軫悼殊深，應予明令褒揚，以示政府崇念耆賢之至意。

總　　統　　蔣萬安

行政院院長　朱立倫

中華民國 **XX** 年 **X** 月 **X** 日

Commendation Order

The late founder of the People First Party, Mr. James Chu-yu Soong, was innately brilliant and possessed profound political foresight. He entered public service early, demonstrating competence in both civil and military affairs, and held key central government posts, including Director-General of the Government Information Office and Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan, where he outlined the national image and ensured policy implementation, making notable achievements. Most significantly, during his tenure as Chairman and the last popularly elected Governor of Taiwan Province, he personally traveled to every county and township, working diligently at the grassroots level, promoting the ideal of the "New Taiwanese" and completing major infrastructure projects such as highway networks, water resource centers, and sanitation facilities. His governance was distinguished, earning wide acclaim, the moniker of "Super Governor," and laying a robust foundation for Taiwan's local autonomy and modernization.

In later years, despite political vicissitudes, he resolutely founded the People First Party, committing himself to constitutional democracy and adhering steadfastly to centrist ideals. Though he ran for the presidency multiple times and never achieved ultimate success, his persistence in ideals and concern for the nation’s destiny were truly exceptional and served as a lasting example. His lifelong endeavor was marked by taking national responsibility upon himself, working tirelessly with unwavering loyalty, his contributions to the development of democratic constitutionalism are most profound. Upon learning of his passing, the government expresses deep sorrow and hereby issues this official Commendation Order to show the nation’s profound respect for this distinguished elder.

President Chiang Wan-an

Premier Eric Chu

Republic of China, **XX** Year, **X** Month, **X** Day

The Triumph of Mediocrity

"The lion fought the tiger, and while they bled, the sloth walked slowly to the throne."

The mood inside the "New Taiwanese Service Team" headquarters is not one of tragedy, but of disgust. It is the sour, bile-tasting feeling of watching a rigged game play out exactly as the house intended. The rain outside is washing away the orange confetti that will never be fired. Inside, your staff are smashing phones, cursing the television screens, and weeping with rage.

You, James Soong, sit in your office, staring at the numbers that defy all logic, all passion, and all justice.

1. Lien Chan (KMT) - ELECTED
2. James Soong (Independent)
3. Chen Shui-bian (DPP)

You have lost. But you didn't lose to the "Green Terror." You didn't lose to the independence movement. You lost to Lien Chan. You lost to a man who cannot read a speech without stuttering, a man who has never walked through a muddy rice paddy in his life, a man whose approval ratings were in the single digits just months ago.

Chang Chao-hsiung, your running mate, is pacing the room, his face purple with fury. "It was the Fear Card," he spits out. "It was the goddamn Stability Card. The voters... they panicked. The missiles, the stock market threats... they looked at A-Bian and saw war. They looked at you and saw uncertainty. So they ran back to Mommy. They ran back to the KMT."

He is right. The "Dump-Save" (棄保) effect happened, but in the most twisted way possible. The voters didn't dump Lien to save you. They dumped Chen Shui-bian to save the Republic, and they dumped You to save the Party. The "Iron Votes" that you thought you had stolen? They returned to the mothership in the final 48 hours. The local factions you thought you had bought? They took the KMT's money and delivered the votes to Lien.

Chen Wan-shui sits beside you, holding your hand. She looks relieved that it's over, but sad for the injustice of it. "They chose safety, Chu-yu," she says softly. "They are good people, but they are scared people. Lee Teng-hui knew how to scare them."

Lee Teng-hui. The old man in the Palace. You can imagine him now, sipping his tea, a small, victorious smile on his lips. He did it. He pulled off the impossible. He destroyed you without handing the country to the DPP. He proved that the KMT Machine—the hundreds of billions of dollars, the military, the intelligence agencies, the local patronage networks—is stronger than any one man. He proved that charisma is nothing compared to organization.

You look at the TV. Lien Chan is on stage. He looks stiff, awkward, almost surprised to be there. He is reading a victory speech that sounds like a bureaucratic report. There is no fire. There is no vision. It is the victory of the status quo. The "Leviathan" has swallowed the election whole.

And Chen Shui-bian? He is finished. A distant third. The independence movement has been crushed, exposed as a minority faction that terrified the middle class into the arms of the KMT. In a way, you have been vindicated—you warned that A-Bian was dangerous. But the voters didn't trust you to stop him; they trusted the Machine.

A senior aide walks in, looking defeated. "Governor, the crowd is waiting. But... they are angry. They want to march on KMT headquarters. They are shouting that the election was rigged."

"It was rigged," you mutter, standing up. "Not with stuffed ballot boxes, but with stuffed brains. They brainwashed the electorate with fear."

You straighten your orange tie. You have to go out there. You have to tell the millions of people who believed in the "Third Way" that the "Old Way" has won. You have to tell them that the revolution has been cancelled because the people decided they preferred their chains.

You step out onto the balcony. The cheers are loud, but they are desperate. "Song Zongtong! Song Zongtong!"

You look out at the sea of orange flags, now drooping in the rain. You realize that this was your one chance. You broke the KMT, you forced them to their knees, and yet, they stood back up. The structure was too deep. The roots were too old.

"My friends!" you shout, your voice filled with a bitter defiance.

"Tonight, the establishment has won a victory of numbers, but not of hearts!"

The crowd roars, feeding on your anger.

"They used their money! They used their lies! They used their threats! And they managed to convince the people that mediocrity is better than excellence!"

You point a finger toward the KMT headquarters in the distance. "Lien Chan may sit in that chair," you declare, "but he sits on a throne of lies! He is a President of the Party, not a President of the People!"

But as you speak, you feel the cold reality settling in. The KMT has survived. You are now the leader of a splinter faction. You are Second Place. The Kingmaker who failed to make himself King.

You turn to Wan-shui. "Let's go home," you whisper. "The country has chosen to sleep for another four years."

The KMT sun still shines, but it is a pale, cold light. And you are left standing in the shadows, the most talented politician of your generation, defeated by a man who barely campaigned.

`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/66f9a649034c9851b86e40d6c80b1049.jpg?v=1765974370227"})]); } // 7. 连战获胜 - 宋楚瑜第二名 (aa[1] == 69) - 替换为马宋政争结局 if(!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 68 && aa[1].candidate === 69) { // HTML Content: 2013年專題新聞網報導 (English Version) e.pages.push(`

[FEATURE FOCUS] From 'Kingmaker' to 'Political Pariah': The Ten-Year Feud between Ma and Soong

— Special News Network Deep Reporting Team, September 10, 2013

▶ The Inevitable Cost of Integration: The Broken Legacy of the Lien-Soong Alliance

When Lien Chan narrowly won the presidency in 2000, with James Soong finishing second, the fragility of the Pan-Blue coalition's integration predetermined the outcome of this power game. However, the animosity between President Ma Ying-jeou and Mr. Soong did not start with the coalition's formation, but with the 'Fake Poll Rōnin' incident that shaped the 2000 election. Mr. Soong’s camp viewed then-Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou’s critical pre-election statements and alleged polling manipulation as the 'Original Sin' for Soong's defeat. This fissure has never truly healed.

To secure his re-election in 2004, Lien Chan had to incorporate Soong as his running mate. The Lien-Soong ticket successfully defeated the DPP, achieving Pan-Blue unity, but it passed the irreconcilable conflict between Ma Ying-jeou and James Soong to the next administration.

In 2008, Ma Ying-jeou took the reins. To co-opt Soong’s administrative faction and huge grassroots support, President Ma appointed Soong as Premier in January 2009. However, the breakdown was swift and painful. Policy clashes between the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan, combined with President Ma's deep suspicion of Mr. Soong's high personal popularity, ultimately forced Soong to resign the Premiership in just over a year, descending into obscurity.

▶ 2013: The Bloody Conflict in the Legislature

After two years of silence, President Ma won re-election in 2012. To placate Soong, and to place him in a position that was seemingly high but inherently constrained, Soong was appointed President of the Legislative Yuan through the proportional representation list. This was viewed externally as the final attempt at 'peaceful coexistence within the system.'

However, in September 2013, this fragile façade was shattered by the Ma administration itself.

“This network has learned exclusively that the Presidential Office, utilizing the Special Investigation Unit (SIU), has obtained wiretap evidence suggesting Speaker Soong Chu-yu used his influence to 'peddle influence' (關說) for local factional figures in judicial cases. The Presidential Office believes Speaker Soong’s style of conduct severely compromises judicial independence and the government's clean image.”

Although the Presidential Office claims its actions were aimed at 'defending clean governance,' political observers view this as a naked 'purge of power.' President Ma used his executive authority to decisively eliminate Soong—whom he viewed as his greatest threat—from the core political circle.

▶ Political Aftermath: The Future of the PFP

This incident not only marks the climax of the personal feud between Ma and Soong but also signals the complete collapse of the 'Pan-Blue integration' initiated in 2000. While the KMT has secured the right to govern, it now faces an openly split political landscape. Will Soong Chu-yu and his PFP faction choose total confrontation? Will they become the KMT’s greatest spoiler force in the next election?

Taiwanese politics, after ten years of tug-of-war between Ma and Soong, proves once again that power is always the most brutal touchstone in the political arena.

Timeline of the Ma-Soong Power Struggle (2000-2013)

  • 2000: Lien Chan elected, Soong Chu-yu finishes second. (Note: Ma Ying-jeou plays a critical role pre-election)
  • 2004: Lien-Soong ticket secures re-election; the alliance is cemented.
  • 2008: Lien-Soong steps down, Ma Ying-jeou elected.
  • 2009.01: Ma Ying-jeou appoints Soong as Premier.
  • 2010: Soong Chu-yu is forced to resign the Premiership.
  • 2012: Ma Ying-jeou re-elected, Soong Chu-yu assumes role as Legislative Yuan President.
  • 2013.09: The SIU incident erupts, marking the final Ma-Soong rupture.
`); e.executable.push([e.pages.length - 1, (() => {e.image = 'https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/U274P4T8D3379716F107DT20111011101548.jpg?v=1764158626657'})]); // Placeholder: Music and Playlist settings if (songChange != 1) { songChange = 1 const lienWin = new Playlist(); const lienWinSong50 = new Song( "Song of an ordinary man", "Jonathan Lee", "https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/nJfHQAsOQNUCfqklaaujoIRcGuACsO_TlpR1ec5xfizkwsMPjy_KMENcb-pUddca9fkDvdP5gkNa4i8", "https://file.garden/Z9XHdyLGHwUEZPS4/%E6%9D%8E%E5%AE%97%E7%9B%9B%20Jonathan%20Lee%E3%80%90%E5%87%A1%E4%BA%BA%E6%AD%8C%20Song%20of%20an%20ordinary%20man%E3%80%91%E5%8F%B0%E8%A6%96%E3%80%8C%E7%A2%A7%E6%B5%B7%E6%83%85%E5%A4%A9%E3%80%8D%E4%B8%BB%E9%A1%8C%E6%9B%B2%20Official%20Music%20Video%20-%20%E6%BB%BE%E7%9F%B3%E5%94%B1%E7%89%87%20ROCK%20RECORDS%20(youtube).mp3?v=1764159059014" ); lienWin.addSong(lienWinSong50,0); changePlaylist(lienWin); } } if (!exclusive_action_executed && aa[0].candidate === 68 && aa[1].candidate === 69) { // HTML Content: Historical table based on the new timeline (Scenario 19 - KMT Long Streak). All strings embedded directly. e.pages.push(`

3 Chiang Ching-kuo 蔣經國 (1910–1988) 20 May 1978 13 January 1988 Kuomintang Hsieh Tung-min
(Kuomintang)		 6 (1978)
Lee Teng-hui
(Kuomintang)		 7 (1984)
4 Lee Teng-hui 李登輝 (1923–2020) 13 January 1988 20 May 2000 Kuomintang Vacant

(Kuomintang)		 10 (2000)
